text: A big, rich, powerhouse all-white high school located nea the freeway into Cape Town. The RUGBY FIELDS are immacula FIFTEEN YEAR OLD BOYS in striped rugby jerseys train with total intensity under the critical eye of the COACH. Right ACROSS THE BOUNDARY FENCE from the rugby fields is area of WASTE LAND leading up to the freeway. There, BLAC AND "COLORED" (MIXED-RACE) BOYS of the same age play a lo game of soccer with a tennis ball. Most of them have bare feet and threadbare, dirty clothes, most of them are noticeably smaller and skinnier than the white boys. Two cultures, separated by more than the high boundary fe
A COMMOTION ON THE FREEWAY intrudes on the soccer game. Horns honking, cars pull over onto the shoulder, people j out.
Lead by police motorbikes, then patrol cars, a white Merc approaches, heading towards Cape Town. Whoever is in the Mercedes has stopped traffic.

The soccer players abandon their game and run for the freeway, whistling and shouting. The rugby players are more disciplined -- or obedient -- do not acknowledge the commotion until the convoy passes right by them. The coach shakes his head in disgust.
Who is it, sir?
It's that terrorist, Mandela. They let him out.
Remember this day, boys. It's the day our country went to the dogs.

A short, STOCK-FOOTAGE MONTAGE which spans the tumultuous four years between NELSON MANDELA'S release from prison a his inauguration as President of South Africa. Footage would include: - Mandela's release from prison - negotiations with the apartheid regime - scenes of white fear and emigration - the horrifying sectarian violence leading up to the

- the khaki-clad AWB (Afrikaner right wing) attack on the World Trade Center (where negotiations were taking place) - the lifting of economic sanctions and cultural boycotts - the lifting of the international ban on the Springbok r team and immediate Test match losses to New Zealand and Australia. - popular black leader Chris Hani's assassination by whit

- black retaliation - Mandela's frantic intervention to keep the country from going up in flames - the election itself, with those incredible images of thousands and thousands of people, black and white, linin patiently, some to vote for the first time in their lives - the African National Congress victory - Mandela's inauguration as President, where he delivers

"Never, never and never again shall it be that this beautiful land will again experience the oppression of one by another, and suffer the indignity of being the skunk of the world." As APPLAUSE FADES ...

Dark. We can make out the FORM OF A TALL MAN SLEEPING ALO at the very edge of the big bed, as if not wanting to rum the blankets too much. On the bedside table, the clock clicks from 4:59 to 5:00. The man's eyes open in the dark, instantly awake. He reac out, switches on the light. NELSON ROLIHLAHLA MANDELA, 76, sits up and gets out of be one movement. He has the physical vigor and energy of someone twenty years younger. 3. The second he is up, he turns around and makes his bed, leaving it as flawlessly smooth as a hospital bed. Or a prison bunk. For this is the discipline of twenty seven years behind b

Dressed in a tracksuit and cross-trainers, Mandela comes the stairs and heads for the front door. This is a nice, big house but it is amazingly modest for President of a wealthy nation, and arguably the most famo man on the planet.

Mandela steps outside, closes his front door quietly, tak moment to savor the air. It is bone dry and cold -- typic conditions in the Highveld at this time of year. It is so quiet that, for a moment, it seems as if Mandela completely alone in the world. The big yard is fenced. There is a small GUARD HOUSE at t driveway gate. When Mandela steps away from the house, A UNIFORMED SOUTH AFRICAN POLICEMAN IN THE GUARDHOUSE pushes the button tha opens the gate.
When the gate begins to open we see that there are TWO GR BMWs parked either side of it.
LINGA MOONSAMY comes to full alert as the gate opens. He a big, scowling man dressed in a suit. He checks the load a pistol, tucks it into his shoulder holster.
Here he comes. Like clockwork.

It makes him such an easy target. 4. Behind Linga, in the back seat, sits JASON TSHABALALA, a naturally tense and suspicious man. Both of them are holl eyed, exhausted, running on adrenaline. They get out of the BMW, fast and quiet. This does not lo good.
As Mandela walks out through the gate, Jason and Linga intercept him.
(traditional greeting in
I see you, father. Mandela's face comes alive as he smiles.

(without breaking stride) Morning boys. How are you? Jason is Mandela's head of personal security, Linga his number one bodyguard. They are both former "terrorists", they are utterly devoted to Mandela.
We're sharp, Madiba.
Good ... good. And how's your mother doing, Linga?
She's much better, thank you.

Good. Mandela picks up the pace. Jason and Linga fall back, so that they are a few steps behind him. They share a quick look. They hate this walk. It scares them. There's no way for it to be anything but completely unsanitary, from a security point of view.
A SMALL DELIVERY VAN drives really fast, blows through st signs.
Mandela strides along the big, wide, tree-lined streets. Jason and Linga shadow him, eyes and ears alert. Up ahead, we see a SMALL, UPSCALE AREA OF SHOPS AND RESTAURANTS.
Mandela, Jason and Linga reach the shopping area. Dark, deserted.
ANOTHER ANGLE of the shops as the small van turns onto th street with a squeal of tires.
The SLIDING DOOR on the van IS OPENED from inside. Too da to see in. Ominous.

Mandela, Jason and Linga pass a HUGE POSTER OF MANDELA in window of CORNER GROCERY. Mandela does not react to this giant picture of himself, Jason and Linga do, proudly -- (A GENERAL NOTE: starting with the window of this grocery there are pictures of Mandela everywhere. Magazine covers newspaper centerfolds, T-shirts, children's art -- as if make up for all the time Mandela's image and words were banned.) -- until they HEAR THE SOUND OF THE VAN tearing towards t They turn, SEE HEADLIGHTS VEERING TO THEIR SIDE OF THE STREET. 6. BOTH MEN DROP THEIR HANDS TO THEIR GUNS. Linga steps in front of Mandela, shielding him, Jason steps out wide, re for anything. Mandela is completely calm. The van screeches to a halt j past them. A GUY jumps out of the van holding a tied BUNDLE OF NEWSPAPERS, which he drops with a thump at the grocery do The guy doesn't see them. The delivery van is gone before the newspapers stop moving. Mandela heads for the newspapers -- he wants to see the headlines. Jason and Linga take their hands off their guns, but they not relax. These are dangerous times. GO IN ON THE TOP NEWSPAPER, which shows a PHOTO OF THE INAUGURATION, and the following words, in Afrikaans: HE C

head_text.subj: WIN AN ELECTION, BUT CAN HE RUN A COUNTRY

text: What does it say?
It says, "He can win an election, but can he run a country?"
Not even one day on the job and they're after you.
It's a legitimate question. Mandela turns and marches for home. Jason and Linga fall behind him. In the east, the first milky hint of day.

The house is now bustling with activity. A pretty member the KITCHEN STAFF sets a single place at the head of a bi formal dining table. A LADY CHEF stirs the porridge, a KITCHEN ASSISTANT cuts fresh fruit. Mandela's PERSONAL SECRETARY, MARY marches out of her sma office with a STACK OF CORRESPONDENCE AND FIVE NEWSPAPERS places them neatly next to the table setting. 7. Outside, Mandela is surrounded by men. Inside, he has surrounded himself with women of all shapes, colors and a to make up for twenty seven years without.

MANDELA SHAVES UPSTAIRS IN THE BATHROOM. The razor is dul Mandela opens drawers looking for another. He opens a dra that is empty but for a WOMAN'S BEADED BRACELET, broken a shedding tiny colored beads. Mandela looks for it for a moment, then closes the drawer looks at himself in the mirror. Mostly, Mandela's face is warm, animated, energetic and this is how we see him, alm all the time. But, sometimes, his face can be a remote, sphinx-like mas that conceals all emotion, all feeling. This is his priso face. This is the face that looks back at Mandela, right now, i the mirror. It is the face of a man whose long, hard jour has marked his very soul. Expressionless, Mandela shaves himself with the dull razo OVER, a COCK CROWS and --
-- a QUICK SERIES OF SHOTS, as the RAINBOW NATION WAKES U
Today marks the beginning of a new era in South Africa -- From the bush to the cities, from shanty towns to ocean-f mansions, PEOPLE START THEIR DAY.

-- as President Mandela takes office in Pretoria, facing issues that range from economic stagnation and unemployment to rising crime -- Some start the day with a tea tray placed next to their b by discreet black hands, some with nothing more than brow river water and half a fire-blackened ear of corn for breakfast. 8.
-- while at the same time balancing black aspirations --
-- with white fears. Click! The TV is turned off by MR. PIENAAR (late 40's) in his very modest, blue-collar house.

I never thought I'd see the day. Mr. Pienaar turns and addresses his son, FRANCOIS PIENAAR 27, a big, blond, almost-handsome man with a fighter's fa and mangled ears. Brutal toughness and honor in his features. A powerful physical presence, possibly dangerou Francois drips with sweat, wears running clothes. Whateve he does, he is strong, fit and driven.
I feel sorry for you, son. You've got your whole life ahead of you. What's it going to be like now? MRS. PIENAAR (late 40's) enters holding some kind of PROT SHAKE for Pienaar.
Don't be so gloomy. (handing over shake) I added vitamins -- there's a horrible flu bug going around. Tell Nerine when you get home.
Thanks, ma.
I'm telling you, Francois -- look at Angola, look at Mozambique. Look at Zimbabwe. We're next. They're going to take our jobs and drive us into the sea. Just you wait.

Magnificent, sweeping government buildings made of carved African field stone, with an Italian tiled roof, situated a hill overlooking Pretoria. The seat of power. Today, the entrance is mobbed with a huge, joyous, multi- racial throng, plus news crews from all over the world. L of new South African flags evident. We move through the throng and swoop up into the air, so we can soar along the outside of the building and LOOK THROUGH THE WINDOWS into the offices of state -- -- where people who worked for the De Klerk regime are packing up, in anticipation of being booted out by the Mandela regime. These characters run the gamut from littl old Afrikaner tea ladies in tears, to the stoic fossils o grand apartheid. They are all white. A good third of the offices are already deserted. The deserted offices have open doors. Through a window, through an open door, we see Mandela and his bodyguards striding down a Union Building hallway. We swoop in through the window --

-- and catch up with the new President. Mandela is regal a magnificent tailored suit. Jason in front, Linga behind PORTRAITS of the architects and champions of apartheid lo down sternly on them as they pass. They pass a WORKER hanging a PORTRAIT OF MANDELA next to of De Klerk, the previous President. ON LINGA, as he smiles at that. Mandela, on the other hand, looks into the empty offices, into the offices being packed up. Up ahead, the double doors to the OFFICE OF THE PRESIDENT are closed. Jason speeds up, opens them, pokes his head i then opens the doors wide.
(with great pride) After you, Mr. President. 10.

Mandela's offices are fronted by a LARGE RECEPTION AREA, already filled with PEOPLE WAITING TO SEE HIM. To one side are his CHIEF OF STAFF'S SUITE of offices, to other side, the SMALL PRESIDENTIAL SECURITY OFFICE. Beyond these are MANDELA'S SECRETARIES, TYPISTS AND ASSISTANTS -- his gatekeepers. Beyond that is the inner sanctum, MANDELA'S OWN OFFICE. The phones are ringing off the hook. Fax machines are chattering. Everyone wants a piece of Mandela. Mandela enters, Jason and Linga behind him.
Good morning everybody.
BARBARA MASEKELA, Mandela's CHIEF OF STAFF (and now Ambassador to the U.S.), emerges from her office, carryin arm load of files, folders and papers --
Barbara, good morning. You've had your hair done. I like it. -- accompanies Mandela back towards his office.
Thank you, Madiba. We need to talk about your cabinet appointments and ministers.
Give me one moment, please. Barbara waits outside Mandela's office, as he enters ahea her.
Mandela stands in the middle of his office, takes a momen savor where he is. 11. Then, he takes off his jacket, hangs it up and is ready f work.
Barbara enters.
-- please assemble the staff for me. Whoever has not already left.
Right now? All of them?
Yes, please.

What's left of the UNION BUILDING STAFF are packed into t DINING ROOM. White faces, bitter and resentful. Waiting t be fired. Through the glass doors, THEY SEE MANDELA APPROACHING DOW THE HALLWAY, Linga and Jason with him.
Here he comes.
He wants the satisfaction of firing us himself. They stand up straight, determined to receive the ax with pride.
Linga and Jason amp up when they see the room full of restless Afrikaners. At the STAFF DINING ROOM DOOR, Mande turns to them.
I'd like you to stay out here, please.
But, Madiba ... 12.
I cannot talk to them if I'm hiding behind men with guns. Mandela opens the doors and enters. Jason and Linga stay outside ... just.
Mandela enters, smiles -- gets not one smile in return.
Gooie more almal.
Does he think greeting us in Afrikaans makes this any sweeter?

Some of you may know who I am. This gets a few bitter chuckles. Mandela is at this best just talking to people, like this. Only, he doesn't just talk to them, he wades in amongst them, shaking hands and making individual contact as he speaks to all of them.
Good morning ... how are you ... thank you for coming at such short notice ... etc.
Mandela is a continual security nightmare. You can see th tension on Jason and Linga's faces as he disappears into throng.
When Mandela reaches the middle of the room, he stops sha hands, and turns slowly as he talks to everybody.
I couldn't help noticing the empty offices as I came to work today. And all the packing boxes. One black man, surrounded by a throng of serious white fa 13.

Now, of course, if you want to leave, that is your right. And if you feel in your heart that you cannot work with your new government, then it is better that you do leave, right away. He can be tough and blunt, when necessary.

But if you are packing up because you fear that your language, or the color of your skin, or who you served previously, disqualifies you from working here now, I am here to tell you, have no such fear.
Wat is verby is verby. What's past is past. We look to the future, now. This is not what they expected to hear.
We need your help. We want your help. If you would like to stay, you will be doing your country a great service. Mandela pauses, to look at the faces. They are receptive.
I ask only that you do your jobs to the best of your abilities, and with good hearts. I promise to do the same.
If we can manage that, our country will be a shining light in the world.
Jason and Linga are right outside the glass doors, lookin and listening. Jason shakes his head.
He wants to win them over, one damn boer at a time.

Mandela heads back through to his office, Barbara, Mary a other assistants forming a phalanx around him. Linga peel off, goes into the security office. Jason stands at the desk of one of the assistants (JESSIE waits for her to finish a call, then:
Molo, sister.
It's still morning? Jason grins.
When you get a chance, can we see the schedule for the month? We need to plan security. Jessie's phone rings.
Office of the President, good morning. Jessie waves Jason off. He crosses to the security office enters.

Once he closes the door behind him, Jason shows his fatig Linga is feet-up on the sofa, sucking on a cup of coffee. Three more bodyguards -- SAM, KWEZI and WINSTON -- slump chairs. Jason grabs coffee, sits at his desk, puts his feet up wi groan.
We need more men.
Did you talk to Barbara about it?
Yesterday. 15. A knock at the door.
That's Jessie, with the schedule.

Come in, beautiful. The door opens -- but what enters is not beautiful. FOUR BIG WHITE COPS in suits enter, Special Branch writte all over them. ETIENNE VAN ECK, HENDRICK BOOYENS, GEORGE WILLEM. The bodyguards stand up like junk yard dogs protecting th territory.
What is this?
Mr. Jason Tshabalala?
That's me. Am I under arrest? Etienne snaps out a crisp salute.
Captain Van Eck and team reporting for duty, sir. Hendrick, George and Willem snap out salutes. Their milit deportment contrasts strongly with the less rigid body language of the black bodyguards.
What duty?
We're the Presidential bodyguard. We've been assigned to this office. (holding out a sheet of
Here are our orders. Jason takes the orders, studies them, face increasingly angry.
You're Special Branch, right? 16. Hendrick nods, sternly. Linga, Sam, Kwezi and Winston rea to that -- there is a long and brutal history between the and the Special Branch.
You'll see that they've been signed.
I don't care if they're signed or -- Jason does a double-take when he sees the signature on th orders: NELSON R. MANDELA.
Wait here. Jason storms out, holding the orders. The four black bodyguards seethe with hostility. The four white bodyguar stare straight ahead, refusing to give ground.
Mandela and Barbara look over a position paper on somethi or other. When Jason knocks and enters, they pause.
Sorry to disturb you.
You look agitated, Jason.
That's because I've got four Special Branch cops in my office.
What have you done?
Me? Nothing. They say they're the Presidential bodyguard. They have orders.
Signed by you.
Yes. They've had special training, those boys -- with the SAS. And lots of experience. They protected De Klerk. 17.
Yes, but --
You asked for more men, didn't you?
Yes, but --
In public, when people see me, they see my bodyguards, too. You represent me, directly. The rainbow nation starts here.
Reconciliation starts here.
Reconciliation? Madiba, not long ago they tried to kill us! Maybe even these four guys. They tried and, often, they succeeded!
Linga, Sam, Winston and Kwezi stare down Etienne, Hendric George and Willem.
Mandela stares at Jason in an entirely different way -- w wisdom, compassion and sympathy.
Yes, I know.
Forgiveness starts here, too. Mandela lets that sink in for a moment. He knows he asks something very difficult, but he demands it of himself to even greater degree.
Forgiveness liberates the soul. It removes fear. That is why it is such a powerful weapon, Jason.
Please try it. Jason exhales. He isn't remotely ready to forgive.
Yes, Madiba. Sorry to disturb you. Jason turns, leaves. Barbara shakes her head at Mandela.
You ask a lot.
Only what is necessary.
As Jason -- very upset -- walks back to security, Jessie holds out a file for him.
Two copies of the schedule. Jason snatches the file, keeps walking.

Thank you, Jessie! When he reaches the security office door, Jason walks rig past, keeps going, has to make a full loop of the recepti area, just to get himself together. Even so, when he gets back to the security office door, J pauses, gathers himself to do something that he knows he' going to hate.
Things haven't eased up one little bit inside the office. The silence is deafening. Jason enters, looks them all ov His face is grim.
Can we get rid of these guys, now? Jason flashes a look at Linga, then -- and this hurts him visibly -- he holds out one of MANDELA'S SCHEDULES to Etienne. 19.
This is his schedule for the next month. Let's look it over for duty assignments.
Right.
What? Linga and the others are shocked.
Jason, I have to talk to you. Outside. Linga virtually pulls Jason out of the office.
Just outside the Security Office door, so they keep their voices low.
How can we trust them?
We can't. (heading back in) This is what Madiba wants, okay. Not okay for Linga, judging by the expression on his face
When Jason and Linga enter, Etienne looks up from Mandela schedule.
Are there any special orders or conditions?
No. Yes. Madiba gets upset if you don't smile when you push people out of the way.
Seriously? 20.
Yes, seriously. It's the new South Africa.
Madiba?
The President's clan name. It's what we call him. The new bodyguards share a look. They're not comfortable with "Madiba".
We'll call him Mr. President. Jason lifts the schedule.

Let's get through this. Still upset and hostile, the black bodyguards look over Jason's shoulder, the white bodyguards look over Etienne' at the month's schedule. Apartheid is by no means dead in this cramped little offi Both teams study and discuss the schedule -- (shop talk t

head_text.subj: USE THIS TO GIVE US A QUICK GLIMPSE OF A DAY/WEEK/MONTH I

text: Etienne shakes his head.
How's he going to do all this? When does he take a break?
He says he rested enough in prison. Jason recoils at something he sees on the last page of th schedule.
Here's a headache.
What? 21.
A rugby match at Loftus Versfeld. British Lions against the Springboks.
It's going to be a headache for the Lions, that's for sure. We're going to donder them.
I don't care about the game. I care that the President'll be so exposed.
To thousands of drunken --
-- sports fans?
Yes. Sports fans.
Who didn't vote for him. Who probably hate him. Who came out of the womb with guns in their hands.

head_text.subj: OVER, THE UNMISTAKABLE SOUND OF PRE-GAME NOISE AT A MAJOR

text: A huge, raucous crowd, almost entirely white and male. Ma wearing the Springbok green and gold. Widespread evidence drinking. Lots of OLD SOUTH AFRICAN FLAGS -- the blue, white and or apartheid flag -- make a defiant statement against the NE SOUTH AFRICAN FLAGS ringing the stadium. On the field, THE RUGBY TEAMS ASSEMBLE and face each othe two lines. The BRITISH LIONS in their white on white with black and red trim, the SPRINGBOKS in their green and gol Like their supporters, the Springboks are all white, but one man, who is "colored" (mixed race). 22. Big, tough, brutal-looking men. Scary. (We may or may not notice Francois Pienaar, standing at the head of the line Springboks.)

At the entrance of the tunnel onto the field, LOTS OF COP blue South African Police uniforms. Behind the line of cops, in the tunnel, we find JASON AND THE OTHER BODYGUARDS but for Linga. They are keyed-up, intense -- none more so than Jason.
(shouting against the

I want your eyes on the crowd at all times. We're staying in the middle of the field. He's going to walk out, shake hands, walk back. Nothing else. Got it? They nod. They are like the players at game time, only th stakes are much higher. Jason looks deeper into the tunne straightens up.

Here we go. Mandela strides down the tunnel towards them, wearing a d suit. Big crowds energize him. His eyes are alive with excitement. One pace behind him, like a huge, dark shadow, comes Ling Mandela gives Jason a look, Jason nods. We follow Mandela and the bodyguards out of the tunnel --

-- onto the field, towards the waiting teams. The crowd rise to their feet. Lots of them jeer Mandela, lots cheer. All the old South African flags are waved at defiantly -- plus some new ones. Mandela waves to them all, smiling proudly. To him, a cro is an opportunity to make new friends. But he stays in th center of the field. 23. Jason and crew are hyper-alert, a human fence around Mand Mandela reaches the rugby players. Waiting for him at the head of the Springbok line, wearin the NUMBER 6 JERSEY and captain's armband, is FRANCOIS PIENAAR. Now we know what he does. Mandela extends his hand.
Good luck, captain.

Thank you, sir. Mandela shakes hands down the line of Springboks, then returns, shaking hands with the British Lions. Quick, perfunctory handshakes. As Mandela does this, we take BODYGUARD POV SNAPSHOTS of crowd, increasingly keyed-up and restless. Time to play rugby. Mandela finishes, waves to the crowd, and begins the walk along the center of the field, back to the tunnel. Crowd noise increases. They know the opening whistle is about to blow. Then, Mandela sees something in the crowd, at field level

head_text.subj: NEW SOUTH AFRICAN FLAG AT HIM.

text: WITHOUT WARNING, MANDELA CHANGES DIRECTION, heads towards this group, towards a wall of his former -- and perhaps current -- enemies. ON JASON: shit!
Stay with him.
Stop him.
Stay with him. 24. With his bodyguards scrambling to stay in position, Mande reaches the stands, hand outstretched, leans into the cro

Thank you for honoring our new flag! Some shake his hand, some -- very pointedly -- do not. The crowd noise takes on an ugly undertone -- Mandela is delaying the rugby. Mandela is undeterred. He's into this one-on-one outreach He turns, looks for more hands to shake -- -- and Jason steps in between Mandela and the crowd.
We're delaying the rugby, Madiba.

Oh, yes, of course. Mandela gives one last wave, turns away. As he does, SOMEONE WINDS UP AND THROWS SOMETHING from th stands. Jason and Etienne catch the movement, whirl, too late. AN ORANGE WHIZZES PAST MANDELA'S HEAD, explodes juicily o the field. Mandela didn't see it, doesn't react. If anything, his sm widens as he heads across the field. The bodyguards close around him protectively, get him back to the tunnel.

Jason signals for extra bodyguards to escort Mandela all way up to his box. Hendrick, the biggest, leads the way. Jason stays in the tunnel, along with Etienne. Both men a in a muck sweat, adrenaline coursing through them.
Why didn't you stop him?
Next time, you try. 25.
Does he do that sort of thing all the time?
Ask my ulcer.
Good thing that was just an orange.
And good thing he never saw it.
Oh, he saw it. He sees everything. (rubbing his ulcer) I hate rugby.

Two international front rows come together with bone- crunching force. Huge, violent men grunt like bulls. The crowd roar vibrat the stadium. The scrum -- a phalanx of eight men locked together against eight -- wheels, buckles, then steadies under the watchful eye of the referee. Fanning out behind each scrum are the backs -- faster, mo glamorous players who will run with the ball, or kick it. The Lions scrumhalf thrusts the ball into the maw of the scrum, the huge men lock up against each other with maxim force. The ball comes out the back of the Lions' scrum, the scrumhalf dive-passes it away to the backs, who flick it laterally to the wing, with lightning speed. The wing lofts a delicate kick just over the onrushing Springbok defenders. The Lions charge the ball, which bounces erratically -- -- right into the hands of the man who kicked it. One las burst of speed, one quick juke to avoid a desperation tac and the wing scores in the corner. As the Lions kicker gets ready to convert the try, we fin the Springboks huddling under their goal posts, hands on their hips, stunned. 26. At the center of the huddle Pienaar bleeds behind his gum guard as, furiously, he tries to inject some fire into hi team.

Concentrate, dammit! Focus! We can beat these guys if we play our game, not theirs! ON PIENAAR, as he realizes he is not getting through. The is dullness, shock in his player's eyes -- -- which all lift to the heavens as the CONVERSION KICK S through the uprights. We FOLLOW THE KICK as it drops past a GIANT SCOREBOARD. STAY ON THE SCOREBOARD as it registers the conversion and shows the score: LIONS - 10 SPRINGBOKS - 0
In the VIP box, Mandela turns his back on the field as th game restarts beneath him and continues in the background He has BINOCULARS around his neck.
Shall we work while we watch? We have lots of promises to keep. Barbara sits to his right, with her ever-present files an folders.

Yes, we do. Mary pours tea at the back of the box. Linga stands two steps behind Mandela. On Mandela's left, sits the PRESIDENT OF SOUTH AFRICAN RU a small man with a small man's ruthlessness and drive.
It's not too late, if the boys can just pick up their game.
If they don't, heads will roll. This is unacceptable.
Come on you bloody bastards! 27. Mandela's expression shows that he has a gentleman's dist for profanity. He turns to Barbara.
Where do you want go first, for foreign investment?
Where the money is. America, England, Saudi Arabia. Barbara makes notes. Mandela lifts his BINOCULARS, but instead of looking at t rugby, he looks at the crowd.

MANDELA'S POV THROUGH BINOCULARS -- Mandela zeroes in on OLD SOUTH AFRICAN FLAG -- the apartheid flag. It is being held by the FOUR KHAKI-CLAD BOERS (FARMERS). Classic Sout African figures from the rural far north, they are alread drunk and suicidally depressed by the turn of events on t field.
Do you see all the old apartheid flags? It's a disgrace. Mandela lowers his binoculars.
It's also a constitutional right.
Along with the apartheid anthem. I know. But it's time people moved on. Mandela grunts, raises his binoculars again.
MANDELA'S POV THROUGH BINOCULARS -- Mandela finds a SMALL KNOT OF BLACK SPECTATORS, holding the NEW SOUTH AFRICAN F and cheering ecstatically.
Look at that. The whites are cheering for the Springboks, the blacks are cheering for the Lions. Mandela lowers the binoculars.
We did that on the island, you know. We supported anyone but the `boks. It really irritated the warders.
Of course it did. ON MANDELA as he thinks about this for a moment, then lif his binoculars to look at the crowd again.
MANDELA'S POV THROUGH BINOCULARS -- on the knot of black spectators, who leap to their feet, reacting to ACTION ON
-- where the Lions score yet another try. This is an ass- whipping.
The conversion sails over the `boks heads. The scoreboard clicks over to: LIONS - 20 SPRINGBOKS - O
Mandela lowers his binoculars, sets them aside, shakes hi head. He knows it's hopeless now. He turns to the Rugby President.
How long until the World Cup?
About a year.
Plenty of time for improvement. 29. The Rugby President can't take it. He stands.
Mr. President -- I wouldn't get my hopes up. We're a damn disgrace. He stomps out of the box, no doubt looking for someone to fire. Mandela gets back to work.

I want to go to India and Indonesia, too. There is a knock at the luxury box door. Linga swings to face the door, alert, as a UNIFORMED DOORMAN opens it. The MINISTER OF SPORT (Steve Tshwete), enters.
Sorry I'm late. He sits down in the empty chair to the right of Mandela.
How's it going?
Very badly. The Minister of Sport checks the score, winces.
Maybe it's just as well. Mandela shoots him a sharp look.
Why?
(bending close, talking

I've just been at a meeting of the National Sports Council executive. There's strong support to drop the Springbok emblem and colors altogether. (gesturing at the field) If they're playing badly, maybe its a good time to make a change. (with barely hidden

MINISTER OF SPORT (cont'd) This could be the last time we have to look at the green and gold. The Minister of Sport shoots a glance at Mandela, to see reaction to all this. Mandela is deep in thought and completely unreadable.

One last, bloody, violent bit of play -- then, mercifully the final whistle blows. Final score: LIONS - 32 SPRINGBOKS - 15. The Lions celebrate. The Springboks head off the field, heads down, shoulders bowed in defeat -- none more bitter disappointed or bloodier than Francois Pienaar. In the stands, the unheard of happens -- the Springboks a booed by their own fans. Not by everybody, but by enough. We STAY WITH THE `BOKS as they trudge across the field, t clatter along the concrete tunnel to their dressing room.

The atmosphere is absolutely dismal as the men undress an shower. Nobody catches anybody else's eye. Huge, powerful, pale bodies have been ploughed purple with rake marks, bruises roasties. Plus, one dark body -- that of CHESTER WILLIAMS skilled wing from the Cape, a reserved and private man. Pienaar takes off his green and gold jersey, sits, begins taking off his cleats. His body hurts. He has been raked, scratched, bruised, and his ankle is swollen. A noble warrior, defeated.
Francois Pienaar's team came to Loftus Versfeld stadium this afternoon, unprepared and arrogant. 31.

Meet BOLAND BOTHA as he tapes his commentary on the test match. He is an ex-Springbok player from the boycott year now turned ponderous, florid rugby commentator. He is a household name, and the last word on the state of the Springboks.
They left 80 minutes later with their tails between their legs, like whipped mongrels.

And I, for one, am glad. Not because we lost, but because there's now no way to disguise the fact that we are completely and utterly unprepared to reenter the world of top-notch international rugby. Boland defines the South African talent for pessimism and negativity.

The Rugby World Cup is now less than a year away, and I, for one, am relieved that we are the host nation, and therefore qualify automatically for the tournament. Because I'm not sure we would get in on merit alone. The Rugby President sucks on a rum and coke, watches Bola with one of his HENCHMEN.
Who gets the axe? Someone has to.
No after-match party this night. Still depressed by the loss, Pienaar stays home with this fiancee NERINE. 32.
Pienaar's team played without discipline, without strategy and without courage.
He's trying to get them to drop me.
He's just bitter because the Springboks were boycotted when he played.
Maybe, but people listen to what he says.
Wearing pyjamas, dressing gown and slippers, Mandela mult tasks, watching Boland Botha and going through a pile of correspondence, scribbling notes or signing his name.

They brought shame upon our nation, and I, for one, can say without fear of contradiction, that today, these fifteen so-called men did not deserve to wear the hallowed green and gold. ON MANDELA: a thought, an idea -- a big one -- is churnin his head. He grunts, turns off the TV, puts the correspondence aside, stands. Mary enters with a glass of milk and some pills, on a tra
Here's your muti. I warmed the milk tonight.
You're too good to me. Mandela takes his pills.
Your daughter called, to cancel her visit this weekend. 33. Mandela pauses, between pills.
Did she say why?
No, she didn't. (making it up) She said to tell you she was sorry. Mandela nods, has a hard time swallowing his last pill.
Do you need anything else tonight?
No, thank you. I'm going to bed. Good night.

Good night, Madiba. Sleep well. Mandela smiles at her, but as soon as he is past her, the smile fades. As he climbs the stairs to his bedroom, his face becomes sadder and older and lonelier. IN HIS BEDROOM, Mandela pauses to take off his dressing g He looks at his bed. It is as smooth and as blank as a sh of paper. He peels back the bedclothes at one corner, slides under and pauses for a moment while reaching for the light swit He switches off the light and lies down, still and straig The most popular man in the world starts and ends each da alone.

A very poor township outside Johannesburg. A stark remind of how much work Mandela has ahead of him. A STAMPEDE OF KIDS runs by. We FOLLOW THE KIDS and find a SMALL, BEAT-UP CHURCH. A no LINE OF THREADBARE KIDS leads from outside into the churc There is a pecking order in the line, based on size.
No pushing now! There's enough for everybody! 34.
At a table near the altar, the kids rummage through bags second-hand clothes under the watchful eye of MRS. COLEMA stout and charitable woman. Next to her, MRS. DLAMINI han out a lollipop and says --

God bless you. -- to each kid. The clothes and lollipops move fast, rhyt kept by Mrs. Dlamini's "God bless yous". The last bag of clothes empties fast as the line of kids reduces until there is only ONE SMALL BOY (SIPHO) left an only one article of clothing. An old SPRINGBOK RUGBY PRACTISE JERSEY. Green and gold. Sipho could use it. His clothes are more holes than anyth else. He looks at the Springbok jersey mournfully.
You're a very lucky boy. It's a real Springbok practise jersey! It's a bit big, but it's warm and it'll last for ever! Sipho shakes his head.
It's yours, take it! Go on. Sipho turns and leaves. Mrs. Coleman looks at Mrs. Dlamin completely confused.
Why won't he take it?
If he wears it, the others will beat him up.
Because the Springboks are playing so badly?
No. Because, for them, the Springboks still represent apartheid.

Eersterust is a settlement and conference location just outside Pretoria. Today it is the location of a full membership meeting of National Sports Council, an ANC organization that is now governing body of all sports in South Africa. A banner draped across the conference center entrance tel us so: WELCOME NATIONAL SPORTS COUNCIL.
An NSC FIREBRAND has the podium and the microphone.
... and now for the next item on our agenda. The hall is jammed. Very few white faces.
The NSC executive proposes a full membership vote on the following motion ... A ripple of anticipation goes through the delegates.
... that as a prominent symbol of the apartheid era, the colors, emblem and name of the Springboks be eliminated immediately ... That causes a stir. The delegates understand how big this is.
... and that all sports teams representing South Africa shall be known forthwith as the Proteas. Excitement and noise level rises. The NSC Firebrand has t shout through his mike.
We will submit this motion to a hand vote.
NSC FIREBRAND (cont'd) In the event of a close count, we will go to a written ballot. (the moment he's been

head_text.subj: ALL THOSE IN FAVOR OF ELIMINATING

text: The NSC firebrand shoots his clenched fist into the air. With a roar, the delegates respond, raising their fists. Unanimous. The Springboks are history. ANOTHER ANGLE, as ONE OF THE OLDER DELEGATES steps outsid make a call.
At his desk, Mandela puts down his phone. Anger in his ey He slams both palms down hard on his desk.

Both bodyguard units (minus Jason) are crammed into the s office. The black bodyguards murmur amongst themselves in Xhosa. (Ad-lib.) The white bodyguards talk Afrikaans (ad- lib). No talk between the two units, only tension. Tension broken with a crash as JASON SLAMS THE DOOR OPEN.
Both units to the cars, right now.

Grey BMW, armored grey Mercedes, grey BMW in a line at th entrance. Jason, Kwezi, Winston and Sam scramble out of the buildin and dive into the lead BMW. Etienne, Hendrick, George and Willem dive into the traile 37.
Brusque, scowling, Mandela marches towards the exit, shad by Linga, flanked by Barbara.
What do I tell the Japanese trade delegation?
I delegate that decision to you.
Do you want me to inform the VP?
No.
We should at least include the Minister of Sport.
No. Mandela heads out to the cars. Barbara has no choice but follow.
Ever the gentleman, Mandela ushers Barbara into the Merce As she gets in:
I strongly advise against doing this. Especially on your own. It ... it gives the impression of autocratic leadership.
Mandela gets in, closes the door.
You risk alienating your cabinet and your party.
Your advice is duly noted, Barbara. 38.
Madiba ... the people want this. They hate the Springboks. They don't want to be represented by a team they cheered against all their lives.
Yes, I know. But in this instance the people are wrong. And it is my job as their elected leader to make them see that. Mandela leans forward to talk to Linga.
Can you tell the boys that Madiba wants to go to Eersterust, very fast. Linga murmurs into his radio. The convoy pulls out, very fast. Barbara makes one last plea.
You're risking your political capital. You're risking your future as our leader.
The day I am afraid to do that is the day I am no longer fit to lead.
At least risk it for something more important than rugby. Mandela looks out the window, says nothing, angry.
Mandela's convoy heads away from Pretoria, very fast.
... and in concluding this historic conference ... 39.

... brothers, sisters, comrades, we in the executive applaud your diligence and courage. The NSC Firebrand and the executive applaud the members. applause spreads until the hall rocks. They are all very pleased with themselves.

Mandela's convoy roars in. Mandela is the first one out, Linga next. Jason and crew scramble to cover the immediate area. Kwezi opens the door for Barbara on the other side. Mandela strides over to Jason, says something to him. Jas looks surprised, turns to Hendrick. Linga's customary scowl intensifies.
As the applause finally begins to diminish, the NSC Fireb turns and nods to a CHURCH CHOIR DIRECTOR, off to the sid The choir director brings his CHOIR onto the stage.
Brothers, sisters ... join us in our anthem. Anyone not standing, stands. The choir director raises hi hands. The choir inhales. Go.

Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrica etc (God Bless Africa) -- But before the first line is fully sung, an ASSISTANT rus out, whispers urgently into the NSC Firebrand's ear. 40. The Firebrand's eyes bug out in surprise. He crosses to t Choir Director, says something quickly. The Choir Director stops the choir in mid-chorus. Consternation everywhere. What's going on?

Brothers, sisters, members of the choir -- we would only interrupt such beautiful music for something truly important. In this case, for someone truly important. (beat, milking it) Please welcome President Mandela! The place goes berserk as Mandela enters, with Linga at h back, and -- surprise, surprise -- Hendrick Booyens leadi the way. Face stern and unsmiling, Mandela walks the length of the hall towards the podium. The delegates press in towards them. ANOTHER ANGLE - Jason coordinates security inside and out Lifts his radio to his mouth.

Smile. ON HENDRICK, as his standard bad bastard scowl suddenly becomes a smile -- which scares the throng more than the scowl did. ON LINGA, the same. ANOTHER ANGLE - Barbara enters at the back of the hall, accompanied by Kwezi. Mandela reaches the podium, turns looks out over the crow face thunderous. When they see his anger, the crowd quietens down quickly.
Brothers, sisters, comrades, I am here because I feel strongly that you made a decision today without sufficient information or foresight. He lectures them like a headmaster. They don't like it. 41.
I am aware of your earlier vote. I am aware that it was unanimous.

Nonetheless, I propose that we restore the Springboks. Restore their name, their emblem and their colors, immediately. Instant and complete silence in the hall. This is utterly unpopular. Shocked faces, especially from the executive a the NSC firebrand. ON BARBARA, as she sees her worst political nightmare pla out in front of her.
Let me tell you why ... Murmurs of disapproval and disagreement begin to rise. Mandela's going to have to row upstream on this one.
... on Robben Island, in Pollsmoor Prison, my jailers were all Afrikaners.
For twenty seven years, I studied them. I learned their language, I read their history, I read their poetry. I had to know my enemy, in order to prevail against him.
And we prevailed, did we not? All of us here ... we prevailed. For the first time, Mandela says something the crowd like
Our enemy is no longer the Afrikaner. They are our fellow South Africans, our partners in democracy. Just as quickly, Mandela loses them again.
And they treasure Springbok rugby. If we take that away, we lose them. We prove that we are what they feared we would be.
We have to be better than that.
We have to surprise them with compassion, with restraint, and generosity. The grumbling and disagreement becomes noticeably louder.
Yes, I know. All the things they denied us. ON HENDRICK, totally engrossed in his job, eyes sweeping across the crowd, feeling the tension.

But this is not the time to enjoy a moment's petty revenge. This is the time to build our nation using every single brick available to us - - even if that brick comes clothed in green and gold. The crowd is growing more restless and rebellious by the moment. LINGA is as alert as Hendrick, tuned in to the jumpy vibe
You elected me.
You elected me to be your leader. Let me lead you now.
Who is with me on this? It's almost as if he's daring them to go against him.
Who is with me? The murmuring becomes a dull roar of argument and disagreement. ON BARBARA as she closes her eyes and lowers her head: th is a fiasco.
As delegates spill out of the conference hall, Mandela's convoy leaves as fast as it arrived. It almost looks as i they're fleeing. 43.

Silence. Mandela looks exhausted, almost gaunt. Facing hi own people like that took it out of him. Barbara stares o the window, chewing her lip, totally stressed out. Linga heaves a great sigh, exhales a truckload of stress.
Jason and his crew travel in stoic silence.
Similar silence from Etienne and crew. It seems like the silence of defeat.
Twelve votes. Twelve!
A luxury. All we needed was one more yes than no.
What if you hadn't got it?
Well, as you know, I am an obedient party member. Barbara snorts disagreement. She is angry at her boss.
I'm sorry, Madiba, but we've got problems everywhere we look. Housing, food, jobs, crime, our currency. You can't keep interrupting affairs of state to placate a minority.
But, I must. This minority still controls the army, the police, and the economy. Without them, we cannot address the other problems. 44.
So this rugby, it's just a political calculation? Life and energy, flood back into Mandela. He sits up agai his seat belt, faces his Chief of Staff.
It's a human calculation.

If we take away what they cherish -- the Springboks, their national anthem -- we just reinforce the cycle of fear between us. ON LINGA, in the front seat. He's not supposed to listen but how could he not?
I will do what I must to break this cycle. Or it will destroy us.

The sound of cleats approaching on concrete. Exhausted footsteps. The DRESSING ROOM ATTENDANT PUTS CASES OF BEER (cans) on a side table, rips them open, backs away -- -- as the Springboks enter silently, faces miserable, shoulders slumped. They've lost another game. One of the players grabs a beer, opens it, takes a gigant
This beer tastes like kuk. -- hurls the beer against the wall so hard it ruptures, sending foaming beer everywhere. ON PIENAAR as his eyes flash and he shoots to his feet.
It's not the beer. Pienaar picks up a case of beers, goes to the angry Springbok. 45.
Take another.
Everybody take a beer. This is an order. The entire team takes a beer, including Pienaar.
A toast ... Pienaar cracks his beer, raises it up. They all crack and raise their beers.
... to the taste of defeat. That bewilders his team.
Drink it. Remember it. And promise yourself never to taste it again. Pienaar takes one long swig --

You're right. It tastes like kuk. -- tosses his beer against the wall, so that it ruptures. Eighteen other beers rupture against the wall. The dressi room is awash with beer and foam -- and re-kindled passio As with Mandela, Pienaar is a leader, on a smaller scale.
Both units crammed into the small office. As usual, neith team talks to the other. Jason enters with two files.

Here's the schedule for the overseas trip. Jason and the boys look over one, Etienne and his unit lo over the other -- and discuss it amongst themselves in Afrikaans. Hendrick says something pointed, which resonat with the others. 46.
What did he just say?
I said --
He asked when we were supposed to sleep.
As well as other basic human functions.
Hey. If Madiba can do it, we can do it.
Mandela addresses the General Assembly, thanking them for their support in the fight against apartheid.
The millions of our people say thank you, and thank you again. Linga and Hendrick are his closest bodyguards.
Mandela addresses diplomats, members of Congress, black leaders at a made-for-TV ceremony on the South Lawn.

I have come here with a message. People of the Unites States of America: Open your markets to us. People of the United States of American: Come and invest in our country. Linga, Jason, Etienne and Hendrick are in on this one -- little island of South Africans in a sea of U.S. SECRET SERVICE PROTECTION.

We are in a COURTYARD behind the palace. Drawn by four wh horses, A ROYAL CARRIAGE (an open carriage) pulls up, sto The courtyard quickly fills with liveried footmen, then security guards. QUEEN ELISABETH and Mandela emerge from the palace. Footm open doors on both sides of the carriage. The Queen and Mandela climb in (the Queen on the right hand side). When they sit down next to each other, Mandela leans over says something to the Queen that makes her giggle ... ... almost. For Queens do not giggle. The carriage pulls forward and these two human icons sit straight, as they get set to face the world.
... and in London, President Mandela made quite an impression on the Queen --
ON TV: footage of Mandela with the Queen, riding down the mall waving to ecstatic crowds.
-- as he concluded a gruelling trip
Mr. Pienaar MUTES THE TV, so that he can deliver the late one-liner to Mrs. Pienaar.

In related news, it was announced that President Mandela will be visiting South Africa this week. Mrs. Pienaar laughs. IN THE BACKGROUND, in the kitchen, a plump, middle-aged Tswana woman washes the dishes and keeps an eye on the TV This is EUNICE, the Pienaar's maid. 48. She does not find Mr. Pienaar's joke amusing.
The PRESIDENT'S JET taxis towards the familiar BMW, Merce BMW convoy.

Mandela disembarks, very slowly. He is exhausted, his fee are swollen, his knee hurts. This is a very different man than the one we have just seen wooing the world. He is met at the bottom of the stairs by Hendrick.

It's good to be home, sir. Mandela just nods. Too tired to talk. Hendrick escorts Mandela to the Mercedes, opens the door him. Mandela takes a step towards the open door -- and stagger Reflexively, Hendrick reaches out, steadies him.
I'm fine. Mandela steps out of Hendrick's hands, holds onto the ope door.
Travelling the world, begging for money, is very tiring. Mandela reaches into his jacket, pulls a SMALL PACKAGE ou hands it to Hendrick.
This is for you. Mandela slides into the car. Once the door is closed, Hendrick glances at the package. We don't see it. It is t dark. But we do see that Hendrick is amazed by it.

Hendrick is being driven home through the Highveld night. chews on something really sticky, chewy. He pauses to dislodge some of it from a tooth, before it pulls out a filling. Then, he resumes chewing.

On the bedside table, THE CLOCK clicks from 4:59 to 5:00. Mandela's eyes open in the dark ... close for a second .. then shoot open again. It takes everything Mandela has to sit up and switch on t light.

The bodyguards' BMW's flank the gate. As the gate opens - -- Linga gets out of one BMW, Hendrick gets out of the ot They are alert. It is freezing cold. Bundled up against the cold, Mandela emerges through the and they close in on him. It is clear that he is pushing himself, physically.
I see you, father.
Morning boys.
Morning, sir. They keep moving. It is too cold for anything else.
How is your family, Hendrick? 50.
Top shape, sir. How about yours? Mandela's smile becomes fixed on his face.
I have a very big family. 42 million people. Then, he stops, turns, heads back towards the house.

I don't think I want to walk today. Hendrick realizes that he blundered, somehow. He shoots a anxious glance at Linga -- who looks at him as if he'd ju committed blasphemy. Mandela goes through the open gate without a word. The ga closes behind him, leaving Linga and Hendrick to watch hi through iron bars. Linga turns on Hendrick.
We never ask him about his family.
But he asks about ours all the time.
Think about it, man. He's separated from his wife. His children ... how often do you see them here?
He's not a saint, okay. He's a man, with a man's problems -- and he doesn't need us reminding him about them. Linga heads back to his BMW. Hendrick stands at the gate, looking in at the house.
Mandela shaves, avoiding his own gaze.

Shaved, showered and dressed, Mandela descends the stairs sits down to breakfast by himself at the big table. He lo at the newspaper headlines, which talk about CRIME RISING THE RAND FALLING, THE MANDELA HONEYMOON OVER etc. etc. Like any other man, Mandela turns to the SPORTS SECTION f relief -- and finally finds something to smile about.
There is a PICTURE OF PIENAAR. Mandela reacts to it, pleased.
As a CABINET MINISTER AND HER ENTOURAGE leave, Barbara enters, holding an envelope.
Hello Barbara. I like that dress.
Thank you Madiba.
This is for you.
What is it?
Your pay checks. You haven't been collecting them. Mandela opens the envelope, looks at a check -- and grunt
What's wrong?
This is terrible.
Madiba, it's what De Klerk got. Plus an increase for inflation. But, Mandela shakes his head, outraged. 52.
Today, President Mandela announced that, in his opinion --
(on TV throughout) -- his salary is too high. Pienaar and Nerine watch the news with MR. AND MRS PIENAA
Dead right. They're all overpaid. IN THE BACKGROUND, once again, Eunice washes the dishes a keeps an eye on the TV.
He has therefore decided to donate a third of his monthly income to charity.
Give me the houses and cars they give him and I'll donate a third of my salary too. Francois' cell phone rings.
(to Mr. Pienaar) You would not. Not in a million years.
Hallo, Pienaar. Whatever Pienaar hears on the phone sends him out of the in a hurry.
Hang on a moment, please.
President Mandela said that he wished to set an example to other leaders and cabinet ministers. 53.
Fat chance. They're lining their pockets as fast as they can. Nerine is interested in the call that sent Pienaar hurryi out of the room. Mr. Pienaar MUTES THE TV.
Must be his girlfriend, hey Nerine.
He knows I'd bloody kill him. ON EUNICE, as eyes and ears alive, she finishes in the kitchen. Pienaar comes back, stands in the doorway, a stunned expression on his face.
What? Who was it? Pienaar doesn't answer immediately.
Told you. It was his girlfriend.
Shush!
I've been invited to tea.
Who with?
The President.
The President of SA Rugby? Count your fingers after he shakes your hand. Pienaar points at the muted TV.
The President. ON THE TV: footage of Mandela with a group of SAUDI PRINC Eunice turns and looks at Francois, wide-eyed. 54. The Pienaar family all stare at the TV, stunned.
He wants me over for tea, week after next. Eunice picks up her handbag, puts on her coat and heads f the door, stops when she reaches Pienaar.
Mr. Francois -- you must tell Madiba that the bus service is very bad, and too expensive. He must please fix it.
Good night everybody.
Good night Eunice, thank you. All eyes on Pienaar.
What the hell does he want with you? Pienaar shakes his head -- he has no idea.
Nerine's modest little car heads towards the seat of powe
Nerine drives. Pienaar wears a blue blazer, grey slacks a subdued tie -- and is surprisingly nervous.
Francois, relax. You've met him before.
I shook his hand on the rugby field, that's all.
You didn't even vote for him. 55.
He's still the President.

He's had dinner with the Queen. With Presidents and movie stars. All I do is play rugby. What if I pull something stupid in front of him? Nerine stops to let Pienaar out. Gives him a kiss, straightens his hair.
You won't. I'll pick you up right here.
Pienaar climbs out of Nerine's car. A pretty sizeable KNOT OF JOURNALISTS rush towards him. Pienaar takes a deep breath. He is a bundle of nerves.
Small office packed with big men.
See who's coming for tea?
My nephew wants me to get his autograph.
Who?
Francois Pienaar.
Who wants to escort him in? Hendrick bolts for the door.
I will. 56.
No autographs.
I know how to do my job, okay. Hendrick leaves.
Who's this Pienaar?
You can't be serious? He's the captain of the Springboks. Linga shrugs, provocatively indifferent.
I like soccer, myself.
Well, you know what they say about soccer -- it's gentleman's game played by hooligans. One the other hand, rugby is a hooligan's game played by --
Ja, ja, I've heard it before. It wasn't funny the first time. Not exactly violin music and roses ... but they are talki to each other.
Hendrick escorts Pienaar back towards Mandela's offices. Hendrick is the bigger man.
Can I ask you a question, Lieutenant?
Ja, of course.
What's he like? They pause at the office door. Hendrick ponders that question for a moment, then: 57.
When I worked for the previous President, it was my job to be invisible. Hendrick opens the door.
This President ... he found out I like English toffee and brought me some back, from his visit to the Queen. Hendrick ushers Pienaar into Mandela's offices.
To him, nobody is invisible.
Hendrick gestures to the waiting area.
That's where you wait. One of his assistants will come for you.
There's a bathroom over there, if you need it.
Okay. Thanks. Hendrick turns to leave, hesitates, turns back.
What are our chances in the World Cup? I mean, for real.
We'll do our best. That, I can guarantee. Hendrick nods solemnly, heads back to security. Pienaar heads straight for the bathroom.
Hendrick enters. Etienne and the other white bodyguards l up. 58.
Well, he's not as big as he looks on TV.
And we don't stand a bloody chance in the World Cup.
Pienaar washes his hands, dries them, dries them again, c his hair, looks at himself in the mirror, adjusts his bla

Pienaar returns to the waiting area, sits. There is a clock on the wall. One minute to four. Four Japanese trade officials traipse out, having just me Mandela. The second hand journeys up to vertical. When it hits 4 o'clock exactly -- -- Mary walks into the waiting area.
Mr. Pienaar? Pienaar shoots to his feet.
This way, please. Mary leads Pienaar back to Mandela's own office, knocks, opens the door.
Go on in. Mouth dry, Pienaar nods -- -- and enters the inner sanctum.
Mandela leaps up from behind his desk, crosses the room t meet Pienaar. 59.
Francois, what an honor. I'm so excited. They shake hands.
Thank you for coming all this way to see me. Pienaar gulps like a fish out of water.
Yes, sir. No problem. Thank you for inviting me.
Tell me. How's your ankle?
My ankle?
I was told you'd hurt it. Has it healed? Pienaar relaxes, visibly. This is small talk he can handl This is Mandela's gift.
The truth is, sir, you never play at a hundred percent, no matter what.

Yes ... yes. In sports, and in life. Come. Sit. Please. (indicating a chair) Take this one. Looking into the light hurts my eyes. They sit in the chairs. A KNOCK at the door, and MRS. BRITS the old Afrikaner tea lady enters, carrying a laden tea tray. Mandela stands again, immediately.
Ah, Mrs. Brits -- Pienaar stands just a beat slower. 60.
-- you are a shining light in my day.
Yes sir. Eyes twinkling, Mrs. Brits puts the tea tray down on the coffee table in front of them. The finest china, cookies a plate.
Mrs. Brits, this is Francois Pienaar. He's the captain of the Springboks. Mandela clearly expects Pienaar to shake hands with Mrs. Brits. Pienaar holds out his hand --
Aangename kennis, Mevrou Brits. -- gently shakes hers.
Ek ook, Meneer.
Shall I pour, sir?

No thank you, I think I'd like to. Mrs. Brits leaves. Mandela does not sit until the door closes behind her. Pienaar only sits after he does. Mandela's manners would not be out of place in Victorian England.
How do you take your tea, Francois?
Milk and sugar, please. Mandela pours tea for both of them. ON PIENAAR, as, just for a moment, he realizes that here is, with the President pouring him a cup of tea. 61.
The English have given us many things, including rugby, but afternoon tea is one of the greatest. Mandela hands Pienaar the tea cup.
Thank you, sir. Both men have big hands. Fine china dwarfed and threatene In the exact moment that both their hands hold the same saucer, Mandela looks Pienaar in the eye.
You have a very difficult job.
I do? I sell gas braais. Mandela lets go and Pienaar takes the tea.
Captain of the Springboks. A very difficult job.
Not compared to yours, sir.
Ah, but then nobody is trying to tear my head off while I'm doing mine. Pienaar grins. True.
It is not so difficult to get people to do their best. And I imagine that anybody who plays for their country does their best, almost automatically.
Or they wouldn't be chosen in the first place.
Yes. But to get people to be better than that?
Better than they think they can be? Now, that is difficult, I find.
Yes sir, it is.
How do we do that? By example? To an extent. But there is more to it than that ... (searching for the right
... inspiration, perhaps. Pienaar is engrossed. This is a master lesson on leadersh from a master.
How do we inspire ourselves to greatness, when nothing less will do? How do we inspire everyone around us?
Sometimes, I think, by using the work of others. Long pause. Pienaar knows to keep quiet.
On Robben Island, when things were very hard, I found inspiration in a poem.
A poem?
A Victorian poem. Just words. But they helped me to stand when all I wanted was to lie down --
But you didn't come all this way to hear an old man talk about things that make no sense.
No! They make a lot of sense, sir.
On the day of a big match, say a test, in the bus on the way to the stadium, nobody talks. 63.
Yes ... yes. Everybody is preparing.
When I think we're ready, I have the bus driver put on a song I've chosen; a theme song. One we all know. We listen together and ... it helps.
Yes! I remember when I was a guest at the 1992 Olympic Games in Barcelona. The whole stadium welcomed me with a song.

At the time the future -- our future -- seemed very bleak. But to hear that song, in voices from all over our planet ... it made me very proud to be South African. It helped me to come home and do better. It allowed me to expect more of myself. A beat.
May I ask what the song was, sir?
Well, it was Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika. A very inspiring song. Mandela looks into Pienaar's eyes.
We need inspiration, Francois. Brown African eyes, blue African eyes meet over their cup tea.
Because, in order to build our nation, we all need to exceed our own expectations. Something passes between them. Whatever it is has a profo impact on Pienaar. 64.
Yes, sir. We probably do.
Cameras click and whirr as MANDELA AND PIENAAR SHAKE HAND for the press. (NOTE that there are NO FLASHES.)
Pienaar walks away from the President's offices, still processing his meeting with Mandela. He seems a little stunned and mystified. Something profound just happened - but he's not quite sure what.

When Pienaar steps outside and sees all of Pretoria -- al South Africa -- stretching away below him, he pauses. He looks at his country in a new way. A BEEP BEEP from Nerine's car interrupts his reverie, as pulls up at the bottom of the stairs.
Nerine drives Pienaar away. Pienaar turns, looks back at Union Buildings.
Hm?
What's he like?
He's ...
... he's not like anyone I've ever met before. An unsatisfying answer. Nerine waits for more. But, she isn't going to get it without prying it out of Pienaar. 65.
Well? What did he want? This is the question Pienaar is wrestling with, too. He thinks it over for long enough to drive Nerine crazy.
Ag, come on Francois. It's like talking to a bloody brick wall. What did he want? Pienaar turns in his seat, looks at her as realization co clear in him ...
I think ...
I think he wants us to win the World Cup.

head_text.subj: A FRAMED PHOTO OF MANDELA SQUARING OFF AGAINST MUHAMMAD A

text: looks down -- -- on Mandela, who is surrounded by HIS GRANDCHILDREN IN LIVING ROOM. Mandela likes the babies. THEIR PARENTS, sho and shepherd the kids, keeping them on their best behavio -- for the PHOTOGRAPHERS shooting this family gathering. Seeing the photographers makes this feel staged. Mandela looks past the photographers, sees his daughter ZINDZI glancing in from the doorway, and then moving on.
Excuse me. Mandela disentangles the babies, stands, leaves.

In the DINING ROOM, Zindzi looks down at a BIG FRONT PAGE PHOTO OF MANDELA AND PIENAAR SHAKING HANDS. She is a modern, cosmopolitan young woman. When Mandela enters, Zindzi looks up from the newspaper w a very Mandela-like grunt. 66.
What do you think?
It doesn't matter what I think.
Yes, it does.
Okay. I think he looks like one of the policemen who forced us out of our house when you were in jail. I don't like seeing you shake his hand. And I'm not the only one. Mandela overreacts.
You criticize without understanding. You seek only to address your own feelings. This is selfish thinking. It does not serve the nation. Zindzi shakes her head, turns, leaves.
Wait. Please. I -- Mandela wants to apologize, doesn't know how. Instead, he pulls AN ENVELOPE out of his pocket, holds it out.
Will you give this to your mother.
What is it?
A bracelet. Zindzi looks into the envelope. In it is the BEADED BRACELET, from earlier, from the bathroom.
Just throw it away.
I don't have the right to. It's not mine. 67.

If she left it here, she meant to throw it away. Only children know how to twist the dagger so deftly. Mandela turns away so that his daughter cannot see his ey A man so at ease with strangers does not know how to talk his own family.

The SAME NEWSPAPER PHOTO of Mandela and Pienaar that Zind was looking at -- only, this time, someone is cutting it very carefully. Eunice. Mr. Pienaar enters to get something from the fridge, sees what Eunice is doing. Eunice stops cutting. Mr. Pienaar looks down at the photo for a long moment. He doesn't know how to react to it.
Mrs. Pienaar said you were finished with the paper.
Ja. Of course. Mr. Pienaar leaves. Eunice keeps cutting until the photo be lifted up. She nods, proud. OVER, A WHISTLE BLOWS, SHARPLY.

On a PRACTISE FIELD at this world-class facility, the SPRINGBOK SQUAD (about 30 guys) sprint to the 25 m line, drops, begins 20 explosive push-ups. NOTE, also, that at least half of the players who faced t British Lions earlier are gone.) 68.
The World Cup is played every four years. Sixteen teams qualify from around the world.
THE MINISTER OF SPORTS BRIEFS MANDELA on the World Cup, w the help of a BIG DIAGRAM ON AN EASEL (just like a March Madness bracket layout, showing all the teams.) The Minis looks ragged, exhausted.
Four pools of four teams each, playing in nine different venues around the country. Two teams will advance from each pool to the quarter finals. Mandela studies the diagram. He loves this stuff.

The Ivory Coast qualified. This is wonderful. (For the record, the sixteen teams who qualified were: So Africa, New Zealand, Australia, England, Scotland, Irelan Wales, Canada, Romania, Italy, France, Japan, West Samoa, Argentina, Tonga and Ivory Coast.)
The Springbok squad leap up after the push-ups, sprint to 50 m line, drop, begin 20 rapid crunches -- -- under the critical eye of the new COACH and MANAGER.
Australia won the previous World Cup. New Zealand won the one before that.
MINISTER OF SPORT (cont'd) They're both clear favorites to reach the finals this time.
According to the experts, we'll reach the quarter finals, and no further.
According to the experts, you and I are still supposed to be in jail. That brings a grin from the Minister of Sport.
The coach blows his whistle.
Again! ON PIENAAR, as he leaps to his feet, leads the charge bac the 25 m line.
You make a personal appearance at the finals, and at the opening match between the Springboks and Australia.
The finals will be broadcast to over a billion people around the world, live.
A billion people watching us! (wheels turning in his
Yes ... yes. This is a great opportunity.
Hands on their knees, sucking air, retching, the squad ha worked their way down the full length of the field.
I reckon you've knocked the stuffing out of them today.
I haven't even begun.
We may not be the most talented team in the world -- but we're going to be the fittest. He blows his whistle.
And back! The squad can't believe their ears. No one moves. Except Pienaar.
Come on boys, let's show him. Staggering more than sprinting, Pienaar heads towards the line.
Shit, what's Pienaar been eating? But, they follow him.
Alone in his office, Mandela looks at the World Cup diagr for a moment, then picks up his phone.
Please call the head of South African rugby for me.

Thirty completely wiped-out athletes. Some are too tired shower, some have made it that far, but are too tired to change. Pienaar has showered and changed and slumps next to his locker. The SPRINGBOK MANAGER enters, followed by the RUGBY PRESIDENT. Pienaar and the boys drag themselves upright. The Rugby President looks them over as if they were his v own stable of race horses -- a stable he's not entirely s he likes.
Afternoon men. It's good to see you working so hard. I have a short announcement.
As part of the PR buildup to the World Cup, you will be conducting coaching clinics in townships all over the country. The players greet this announcement with complete silence
I know you have plenty on your plates already -- but this is a request that comes from the top. (looking at Pienaar,
The very top. The Rugby President turns on his heel, and leaves, follow by the Manager. The players say nothing for a long moment, but body langu alone shows that they are completely disgusted.
This is complete crap.
Are we some kind of circus act now? 72.
We don't have time for kuk like this. The boys are getting angrier by the second.
They expect us to play our best, to give our bloody all, then they add to our bloody workload ... The lock turns to Chester.
What do you think about this, Chester? All eyes on Chester, as if the poor guy is a magic guide world they barely understand.
I try not to think. It interferes with my rugby. The perfect answer for these guys.
See! Now there's a rugby player. Talk to them Francois.
Make them see that this is a waste of time we don't have. All eyes on their Captain -- who shakes his head, no.
I'm not going to talk to them.
Why not?
Whether we like it or not, we're more than just a rugby team. We're ... we're ambassadors inside our own country. And we might as well get used to it. Silence. Rebellious silence. Then:
Is this you speaking, or Mandela? 73. Pienaar's eyes are fierce. He needs them to see how serio he is.
You know me better than that.
Times change. We need to change, too. It is clear that much of his team disagrees with him.
CLOSE-UP ON A TV -- horrible, startling images of the OKLAHOMA CITY BOMBING.

We're looking at the remains of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, America, which was destroyed today in a massive explosion. PULL BACK to reveal that we are in Mandela's offices. Barbara, Mary, other assistants look on. So do the bodyguards. All faces stunned, appalled. Mandela approaches slowly from his office, drawn in by th horrible, irresistible images. He stands behind his peopl

No one has claimed responsibility yet, but authorities say that the timing and target mark this as the work of white, right-wing fanatics. An act of revenge for the FBI killings in Waco, Texas. Jason and Linga share a pointed look. South Africa is a global leader in white, right-wing fanatics.
The explosive, a truck bomb, was apparently a simple mixture of commonly available industrial and agricultural materials.
That's all we need.
A homemade explosive from materials every boer already has. Then, Jason realizes that Mandela is standing right next him.
So far, the official death toll stands at over a 100 people, which includes at least 12 children from a day care center in the Federal building. Mandela turns to Barbara.
Please call President Clinton for me. I wish to offer him our condolences. Mandela turns to Jason, eyes deep and dark.
Do you see why forgiveness is essential, Jason?
Revenge only begets revenge. As Mandela walks back to his office, there is a look of u sorrow on his face.
A luxury bus heads along the freeway.
The Springbok squad rides in style. Most are wearing tracksuits, most are asleep. Pienaar is awake.

The same township where Sipho rejected the Springbok rugb jersey. At one edge we find what passes for a SOCCER FIELD. Just littered rectangular expanse of Highveld winter dirt. 75. TV VANS and a very nervous SPRINGBOK MANAGEMENT CREW driv the edge of the field, stop, get out -- -- and are immediately mobbed by THREADBARE, EXCITED KIDS many of them begging for cash and candy. SIPHO in the thi of things. One of the Springbok management crew pulls a ROLLED BANNE two spiked poles out of their van. Mallet and banner in hand, the management crew head to th edge of the field, mobbed by shouting, whistling township kids. They hammer one pole into the ground, unroll the banner ( from the back so that we can't read the words), get set t hammer the second pole into the ground -- -- except that there is a SMASHED BEER BOTTLE in the way. Broken glass everywhere. They look at the broken glass, then turn and look across field. Broken glass glints in the low sun, all over the field.
They can't play on this.
When are they due?
Fifteen minutes.
Plenty of time. He reaches into his wallet, pulls out a R100 note (about $17), holds it up high. The kids yell for it.

head_text.subj: THIS GOES TO WHOEVER COLLECTS THE

text: Mayhem, as kids sprint out across the field, hunting for glass. Sipho goes for the tiniest, most treacherous shard

The bus hits a rut in the dirt road with an almighty jolt which wakes the sleeping Springboks. They look out of the windows and see the absolutely helli outskirts of the township. Every possible incarnation of poverty, as far as the eye can see. This shocks them. Most of them have never been anywhere l this township.
Shit, I'm glad I don't live here.
The driver sounds the horn, as they pull into the townshi
The bus pulls up at the field --
-- which is covered with kids on their hands and knees.
What the hell are they doing? The driver sounds the horn again, and the kids on the fie sprint for the bus, hands and pockets full of broken glas
Don't forget, we've got TV cameras on us at all times.
What a bloody joke.
As the kids approach the bus, they dump their broken glas under the banner, which reads -- 77.
-- brown, green, white, blue shards tinkling and piling u like lethal jewels, backlit in the low winter sun. One of the big kids gets the R100. Attention focussed on

-- until the bus door opens with a loud hiss of hydraulic and the Springboks exit, one by one. Pienaar first, with a huge NET BAG OF PRACTISE BALLS over shoulder. The Springboks are all so big, so strong, so healthy, the look like gods, or aliens, emerging from a spaceship. The kids go quiet, awed and uncomfortable. Until Chester Williams steps off the bus, and there is a collective sigh of recognition and wonder. Now, the kids can relate to the Springboks. Even Sipho, w looks on from the side of the field. Springbok management notes it. The TV crews note it. Pienaar notes it.
Okay Chester -- I reckon you're up.
What am I supposed to do?
What you do best. Pienaar turns to the throng.
A roar. They all do. Pienaar opens the net bag full of rugby balls, gives a ba to Chester.
Let rip. 78. Chester boots the ball out over the crowd, high and incredibly far in the thin winter air. (60 yards, easily. Pienaar tosses balls to the others.
Let's do our best. One after another, the Springboks kick the balls high int the air.
Go get them! The kids go after them. Sipho stays on the sideline.
Barely controlled chaos. Each Springbok works with one ba and a group of kids. There are THREE THEMES to this monta FIRST, a primer on the basic rules of rugby, with demonstrations.
Who here knows the first rule of rugby?
Me!
What is it?
Only hit the other players when the ref isn't looking! Laughter. A good ice-breaker.
No. The first rule of rugby is you can only pass the ball backwards or sideways. Pienaar demonstrates. (NOTE: All the rules are demonstrated.)
- If you drop the ball, or pass it forwards, you scrum for possession. - This is a scrum. - You kick forwards.

VARIOUS SPRINGBOKS (cont'd) If you kick it out of bounds, you throw it back in to a lineout. - This is a lineout. - You score in four ways: a try, when you dot the ball down behind the try line. That's five points. - Another two points when you convert the try by kicking the ball through the uprights. - Three points for a penalty kick. - Three points for a drop kick. - Have you got all that?
No!

Agh, bugger it, let's just run and pass. Whoever drops the ball does pushups! SECOND, as the players work with the kids, they get into Much to their own surprise, they enjoy the energy, they e the kids, they enjoy the giving. Even the grumpiest, most conservative Springbok.

Okay. Who wants to scrum against me? One huge man scrums against a horde of kids. He pushes th backwards with a roar -- then lets them push him backward They love it, the cameras love it. THE THIRD THEME shows the emergence of Chester Williams a the face of the Springboks. The crowd of kids around him twice as big as any other player's crew. Given Chester's basically shy nature, he finds it all a bit overwhelming. The TV cameras follow him even more closely than they fol Pienaar. AT ONE POINT, an errant pass puts a rugby ball right at Sipho's feet. He hesitates, then picks it up. He doesn't just hold it, he feels it. END THE MONTAGE as the luxury bus pulls away, surrounded horde of cheering kids, many of whom hold new rugby balls under their arms. One blast on the horn, one answering cheer from the kids the bus slowly accelerates away.

A cabinet meeting in the rainbow nation, with Mandela at head of the table. The MINISTER OF THE ENVIRONMENT is making a presentation about a campaign to put an end to littering by plastic ba Behind him is a VERY DRAMATIC SLIDE IMAGE of a rural barb wire fence festooned with wind-blown plastic bags.

-- and in addition to the nationwide PR campaign, we propose that all retail outlets charge a nominal fee for plastic bags -- Mary enters quietly, slips a piece of paper in front of Mandela, who reads it, holds up his hand.

Mr. Minister, please forgive me. This sounds excellent, and we will return to it, but if you'll indulge me for just one minute -- Mandela nods to Mary, who switches on a big TV on the wal which shows NEWS FOOTAGE OF THE COACHING CLINIC in the township. When we see the FOOTAGE OF THE LOCK SCRUMMING WITH THE KI Mandela laughs, delighted, turns to his cabinet.
You see, that picture is worth any number of speeches.
Mr. and Mrs. Pienaar watch the same report ON TV. Mr. Pienaar has quite a different reaction to Mandela's.
Tell me something -- how does this help them win rugby matches?

ESTABLISHING SHOT from the air of Cape Town, one of the m beautiful cities in the world. We see the Cape Peninsula, the harbor, the city itself draped around the shoulders o Table Mountain like a multi-colored Mediterranean shawl. On its descent towards Cape Town airport, a SOUTH AFRICAN AIRWAYS JET flies across the view with the smiling face o Chester Williams painted on the fuselage.
This is Boland Botha coming to you live from Cape Town airport --
From a position near an IDLING LUXURY BUS, Boland speaks his mike.
-- where the Springbok flight has just landed.
ON THE APRON, the team disembarks. The boys are dressed in Springbok blazers, slacks and tie A magnificent sight. Gladiators in top shape, faces appropriately stern.
People -- white people -- clap and cheer as the team ente the building.
The green and gold have one week to put the finishing touches to their gruelling training program -- The team feeds on the energy. They walk taller, faster, closer together.
-- and I, for one, have to admit to being cautiously excited. 82.
ON BOLAND BOTHA, next to the bus.
I say cautiously, because in my humble opinion -- Behind Boland, the Springboks get into the bus, fast.
-- this team has been over-trained on the field, and over-committed off it.
A beautiful Cape Dutch style mansion. Mandela stands in h HOME OFFICE, watches Boland on TV. The MINISTER OF SPORTS with him.
