Which makes beating a powerhouse Australian side in the Cup opener next week a tall order, especially since this is an inexperienced team with a history of coming up short in big matches. This is Boland
Mandela switches off the TV.
Around the world -- objectively -- what are they saying about our chances against Australia?
Everyone thinks they'll beat us. And if they do, we'll have to go through England and the All Blacks just to get to the Final.

So it is very important that we beat Australia. (to Minister of Sport) Thank you. 83. The Minister leaves. Alone in his office, Mandela sits, thinks, gets a sheet o paper with his PERSONAL LETTERHEAD on it, uncaps his foun pen. OVER MANDELA'S SHOULDER, we see him write, and then underline, the title INVICTUS by W.E. Henley. BARBARA KNOCKS, pokes her head in.
The Cabinet Ministers are here to brief you on the trip to Taiwan.
I'll be right out. From memory, Mandela writes the first line of the poem: Out of the night that covers me ...

The luxury bus comes around a bend in a leafy suburb of C Town, right under the flanks of Table Mountain. Ahead, we see NEWLANDS STADIUM, home of the World Cup ope between the Springboks and Australia. A magnificent old stadium in a beautiful setting.
All eyes on the stadium as the bus idles past, very slowl This is a coach move.
One week, boys. Excited faces become grave, serious. The bus goes quiet. Coach nods to himself, pleased.
The bus pulls away. 84. WE STAY AT NEWLANDS STADIUM -- and SWOOP UPWARDS until we looking down on the stadium and surrounding streets. This AERIAL SHOT BECOMES A BIG MAP --
-- pinned to a board in the security center.
We need snipers on top of the stadium and these surrounding buildings. Jason leads the meeting. He uses an old-fashioned pointer All of Mandela's security detail present, plus LOCAL COP BRASS.
Not a problem.
We want these two approaches completely sanitized.
Two approaches?
We're not going to decide which way we bring him in until the very last moment.
We need uniforms, plain clothes, sharp-shooters ...
And sniffer dogs.
Yes. No truck bombs, no Oklahoma City. The locals stir, share a look. This is going to be a nightmare.
We've got an army unit on standby at Silvermine, if you need more men. Not an option the cops favor, judging by their faces. 85.
We're not taking any chances, okay. The President's going to be very exposed.
Much too exposed.
The silver Mercedes tools into Cape Town past Groote Schu Mandela travels with Barbara, who opens her first file of journey -- but is forestalled by her boss.
Barbara, I have been studying.
For the summit in Taiwan? Good.
No. Not exactly. Mandela hands Barbara a folded SPORTS SECTION.
Test me. Barbara unfolds the sports section -- -- to reveal COLOR PHOTOGRAPHS OF THE SPRINGBOK SQUAD. A collector's pull-out. Barbara looks at the photos, shakes her head.
They look like thugs. Mandela just smiles at that remark.
Block out the names. See if I can recognize them. Barbara gives her boss a put-upon look -- this is such a waste of time! -- but blocks out the first row of names. Mandela points at the first photo.
Andre Joubert.
Gavin Johnson.
Did I get them right?
Yes, Madiba.
(immensely pleased with
This is how I used to study in law school. (next photo is of Chester) Unfortunately, Chester is far too easy to identify. But that will change. It must.

The entire Springbok squad has been on a training run thr Cape Town, on ordinary streets, through ordinary people. (This is unthinkable in top-level sports anywhere else. I really happened.) When they are recognized, drivers toot their horns, pedestrians cheer, kids on bicycles ride with them (mostl still white). As they approach the hotel grounds, Pienaar surges to the front, so that he can give them a message as they pass through the hotel gate.
Players-only meeting in the team room after dinner.

Normally a conference room, now equipped with fridge, poo table, ping pong, sofas, TV etc. The entire team has assembled, minus Pienaar. A quiet air Serious, relaxed. Pienaar enters, holding a sheaf of XEROXED PAGES, begins hand them out.
What's this? Homework? 87.
Sort of. The players look down at the pages. ON A PAGE: the words to Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika, in Xhosa. One by one, the players look from the page to Pienaar.
Cappie? What's this?
We need to learn it. We can't just mouth the words anymore.
Nobody cares, as long as we win matches.
They do care.
It's their song, not ours.
It's a terrorist song.
They used to arrest you for singing it.
And now it's one of our anthems. But he's talking to a deeply conservative group of guys.
Cap. You know I leave my guts on the field for you, and you know I'd follow you into a fight anywhere, any time. But this ... The hooker crumples the page, is about to throw it away.
... I can't even read it. I definitely can't pronounce the words. One look at his men, and Pienaar knows he has hit a wall. 88.
Okay, boys. It's optional. Take it if you want to. The players are relieved. Pienaar looks down at the sheet paper for a moment, then looks up at the guys.
It means "God Bless Africa".
Which you have to admit, we could use. Nonetheless, most of the players crumple the pages, toss into the closest trash can.
Tell us, Mr. President, have you always been a rugby fan? Mandela appears with Boland Botha on his show, under a ON TEAM, ONE NATION banner.
People do not realize that I once played rugby myself, when I was a student at Fort Hare. It is a very rough game. Almost as rough as politics. Boland laughs.
SHOTS OF BOOZE BEING DELIVERED to people's houses all ove the country by BOTTLE STORE DELIVERY VANS (a very South African alcoholic enabling service). Lots and lots of boo
How do you think the Springboks will do?

I think they will do very well. Their level of commitment is tremendous. 89. THE SPRINGBOKS TRAIN on an isolated field at the SILVERMI ARMY BASE outside Cape Town. Tactics and refinements, not fitness training.
Now, it's been said that you used to support any team who played against the Springboks.

Obviously, that is no longer true. I am one hundred percent behind our boys. JASON, ETIENNE, LINGA and HENDRICK stand anxiously outsid Newlands Stadium. One of them points to the top of a tall building nearby -- a Eureka! moment, for reasons we don't understand.
After all, if I cannot change when circumstances demand it, how can I ask others to?
A SOUTH AFRICAN DEFENSE FORCE HELICOPTER hovers over the building next to Newlands stadium.
IN THE HELICOPTER, Mandela, Jason, Linga, all wearing rad headsets. All wearing suits, as if for a state occasion.

We're going to land you on top of that building. We'll own the road between it and the stadium. Mandela likes it. Jason gives the pilot a nod and they take off down the peninsula towards Silvermine Army base. FROM THE HELICOPTER, MANDELA LOOKS down at his country, a finds it good. 90.
Helicopter against spectacular scenery.

Mandela points down. Jason and Linga look. POV FROM THE AIR: They can see the Springboks practising right below them, on the army base. Mandela pulls out the SPORTS SECTION with the Springbok t on it. His study guide. He takes a last minute glance at as the helicopter loses altitude.

Mandela's helicopter lands at the edge of the field, and brings practise to a halt. ON COACH -- not happy, but what's he going to do. Mandela springs out of the helicopter, energized, excited Linga and Jason with him. The players assemble in a loose, semi-formal unit. Not a line, but orderly. (We may or may not notice that Chester Williams is missing.) Pienaar stands at the front, relaxed. He's an old hand wi Mandela, by now.
Francois, gentlemen -- forgive me for interrupting your work the day before such an important match ...
... I just wanted to wish you good luck, in person. There is a naughty twinkle in Mandela's eye.

And sometimes, very seldom, as President, I am allowed to do what I want. They all laugh. 91. Mandela wades in amongst them, leaving Linga and Jason behind. Picture this: Behind the barbed wire security of a modern South African military base, a tall, regal black man in h 70's is surrounded by huge, sweating, battered, brutal- looking white men --
Mr. President, this is --
I know who this is.
Good luck, Andre. (shaking hands with all of

Good luck Brendan, we're behind you all. Japie -- etc -- every single one of whose names he has committed to memory. Statesmanship is often about attention to detail. The players are awe-struck. (FOR THE RECORD: Andre, Gavin, James, Japie, Christiaan, Brendan, Hennie, Joel, Johan, Joost, Marius, James, Chris Pieter, Garry, Mark, Kobus, Hannes, Krynauw, Ruben, Franc Robby, Adriaan, Rudolf.) CUT AWAY to Jason and Linga, who are amazed by what they' seeing.
Did you ever imagine this?
How could I? By the time Mandela has shaken every single player's hand has won the team over, coach and manager included. They glow. And then, Mandela frowns, steps back, looks at all of the
But where is Chester? Pienaar doesn't answer immediately, he looks at his coach first. Coach nods. 92.
He's injured, sir. His hamstring. We're trying to keep it quiet.
Is he out for the whole tournament?
With hamstrings, who knows?
We'll miss him.
The whole country will miss him. A somewhat sour note to leave on. But it's about to be rescued.
Mr. President, sir --
Yes, Hennie.
-- this is for you. From us. The huge, thick man holds out a GREEN CAP with gold pipin and a Springbok leaping above the visor. Mandela takes the cap as if he has just been given a holy relic.
I am honored. Truly honored. Mandela runs his finger over the embroidered Springbok leaping across the front of the cap.
Good luck gentlemen. Your country supports you, completely. The team applauds, beaming, glowing. Mandela turns to go back to the helicopter.
Francois, walk with me. Pienaar walks Mandela back towards the helicopter. 93.
I have something for you. Mandela reaches into his jacket, pulls out an ENVELOPE WI THE PRESIDENT'S LETTERHEAD on it. Gives it to Pienaar.
This helped me, many times. Perhaps it will help you, too.
Pienaar holds the envelope, stares upwards at the rising, departing helicopter, as do the rest of the team -- until Coach blows his whistle.
Enough fun and games! We've still got work to do.
Jason paces restlessly, going over his mental check list, making sure he hasn't missed anything.
Mandela reads, scrawls comments, signs papers from a big pile. Mary enters with his glass of milk and his pills.
It's time for bed.
I think I'll stay up a little longer. The country is excited tonight.
You need to sleep. The doctor said.
The doctor has no sense of occasion. 94. Mandela turns on the TV, begins flipping channels. Rugby, rugby, rugby. Mandela is sucked in. Mary sighs.
The coach and the manager. Cats on a hot tin roof.
There's nothing more we can do. The game plan's good. It's just a matter of the boys executing it tomorrow.
That's Pienaar's job. It's in his hands, now.

Room dark but for one small desk light. Pienaar stands at the window, looking out across Cape Town. He is deep in thought. Pienaar turns away from the window, goes to the desk, whe under one small light, we see "Invictus", the poem Mandel wrote out by hand. Pienaar begins reading it. There is a soft knock at his door. Pienaar goes to it, opens it. It is Nerine, accompanied by a cop. Pienaar nods at the cop, steps back so that Nerine can en As soon as the door closes behind her, Nerine says:
You know the best thing about you being the captain?
Uh ... the honor?
You don't have to share a room. Nerine gives Pienaar a scorching kiss. He resists ... the responds -- then pulls away. 95.
Francois, come on. It's been weeks.
Uh uh. I need to be angry for tomorrow. Nerine takes a deep breath, nods, turns away -- and sees poem on Mandela's personal letterhead.
What's this?
A poem. From the President.
How does a poem help you play rugby?
The same way your visit does.
Inspiration. OVER, REFEREE'S WHISTLE BLOWS HARD AND SHARP.

A massive crowd roars. The Wallaby flyhalf runs forward, puts his boot into the ball, sends it soaring towards the waiting Springboks. The Springbok lock rises high into the air, supported on sides, takes the ball out of the air perfectly -- -- just as the Wallaby pack closes in and huge men meet w an adrenaline-fueled crunch of bodies. The World Cup has begun at last.

But not for Chester Williams. Clad in Springbok blazer an tie, he sits behind the coach, the manager and the reserv in the stands -- and almost succeeds in hiding his utter disappointment at not being on the field. 96.

Mandela looks on, calmly. The Minister of Sport isn't lat for this match. The President of Rugby is pale with nerve Behind Mandela, stand Linga and Hendrick. The VIP box is safe place, but Jason isn't taking any chances.
Jason prowls through the stadium, talking constantly on h radio. Hunter's adrenaline.

Back to action on the field. The highlights we see here should match the rugby primer saw in the township. This continues the education of thos who do not know rugby. So, for instance, we see a ball knocked forward, and the resulting scrum. We see a ball kicked out of bounds, and the resulting lineout. We see scintillating passing, rucking, mauling, tackling, strategic kicking at it's very best. Both teams are crisp and strong.

-- with SHOTS OF THE SECURITY ARRANGEMENTS (snipers, lots lots of uniformed cops inside and out, sniffer dogs etc. overseen by Jason) -- -- with SHOTS OF THE CROWD, which, unlike the earlier tes against the Lions, is completely and passionately united behind the Springboks (all commentators talk about the extraordinary passion of the crowd, that day) -- -- always returning to the VIP BOX, where something interesting is taking place right behind Mandela: Linga Moonsamy, the rugby scorner, the soccer lover, loses his scowling reserve and gets sucked into the game. 97. When a ball soars between the uprights and everyone in th box groans, Linga leans towards Hendrick and asks:
What happened?
They scored. When another ball soars between the uprights and the crow roars, Linga asks again:
What happened?
We scored. A third ball through the uprights. Before Linga can ask:
They scored again. A fourth ball, to the joy of the others in the box.
We scored?
Ja. We're tied. A fifth ball through the uprights, and the crowd goes wil

We're up by three. ACTION ON THE FIELD, as a Wallaby drive combining backs a forwards moves relentlessly towards the Springbok try lin Six times the drive is stopped by Springbok tackling, but Wallabies keep possession and, on the seventh wave of the assault score a beautiful open try, which is converted. A ripple of concern goes through the crowd -- -- and the VIP box.
They're ahead?

By four. Nerves in the box. 98. But not on the field, as Pienaar starts a drive with a ta we feel ourselves, resulting in a change of possession -- -- and a stunning, open field try scored in the corner by Springbok wing, who raises his fist in the air, after juk the last Wallaby to try and tackle him. The crowd roars. In the VIP box, Mandela is on his feet, shaking hands wit everyone he can reach, including Linga and Hendrick, and waiter. The difficult, angled conversion is missed.
What does that mean?
We're only ahead by one. Another penalty kick.
We're ahead by four. A drop goal.
By seven. An incredible try by the Springbok fly half.

By fourteen. Everyone dares to dream. The classic South African pencha for pessimism begins to abate. Two things to note: The crowd roar grows and grows and gr and is echoed in the VIP box. Even Jason turns to look at the action on the field -- but only for a second. Also, t match serves as the coming-out party for the SPRINGBOK FL HALF, who scores 22 of South Africa's 27 points this day. SUDDENLY, A REFEREE'S WHISTLE CREATES PANDEMONIUM on the field, in the stands, and in the VIP box.
What happened?
We won! 99.
We did? Mandela shoots to his feet, pushes his chair away and beg the famous "Mandela shuffle" -- a very cool African boogi that is one of his signature moves. ON THE MANDELA SHUFFL

-- the same shuffle hours later, at a VIP party. Mandela changed clothes, wears one of his Indonesian-inspired "Ma shirts" and dances energetically with the absolutely stun TROPHY WIFE of one of the VIP's.
You must be very pleased!
What man would not be pleased to be dancing with a beautiful woman like you?
Oh, Mr. President, you're exaggerating.
Indeed not. My father was a Xhosa chief, and therefore a polygamist. As you know, I am not.

But when I look at you ... I envy my father. The man is a major flirt, and really enjoying himself. Bu once again, he is dancing with a stranger -- -- and, when we get close to his eyes, we realize that Mandela is pushing himself way past empty.
Jason is asleep on his face, in his suit and shoes.
Big party, spilling onto the streets. Most of the partier are white. Black South Africans look on, or serve drinks. We follow the crowd into a big sports bar --

-- where the Springboks are pounding beers and blowing of the steam of months of training grind, plus a huge win. Even though most of the players are with their wives or girlfriends, pretty, single women crowd them, two and thr deep, men pay for round after round of beers. Pienaar and Nerine are part of the action. Then Pienaar g a TEXT MESSAGE which makes him shake his head, give Nerin chagrined look. He grabs the Springbok closest to him, puts his mouth nea the player's ear and screams again the hubbub:

head_text.subj: COACH'S RUN, NINE A.M. SHARP. PASS

text: The Springbok shakes his head -- bloody coach -- grabs th player next to him, repeats it. Pienaar watches the message travelling through his team - and grins. Then, something catches his eye on one of the big overhea TV's. ON THE TV: news footage of the Mandela victory boogie. Th boogie is followed by a quick "How far we have come" type montage. One of the images shows an island ringed by roug surf. Pienaar gets an idea.

Pienaar leads his hung-over, sleep-deprived team on a ver slow jog through the mostly empty streets. 101. When he gets to an intersection, he sneaks a peek down at palm of his left hand. CLOSE-UP ON PIENAAR'S HAND, where he has drawn a crude st map. Pienaar takes a left at the intersection.
Another intersection, another peek at the map on his hand and another left turn, takes the team --
-- back onto the waterfront, to an idling FERRY BOAT, whe the coach and the manager wait for them -- along with the player's wives and girlfriends.
I hope you're not that slow next week. Pienaar grins, stops. The team stops around him.
What's going on?
A change of pace.

The ferry pulls away from the waterfront, with the team o board, pulling on tracksuits against the cold sea air. It is early winter. The seas are fairly rough. So are the stomachs of the `boks who partied hard last ni
Who's bloody idea was this? ON PIENAAR, innocent as a lamb. 102.
Behind the ferry, Cape Town and Table Mountain, in all th glory. Ahead of the ferry, one of the most notorious island pris in modern history -- -- ROBBEN ISLAND.

Robben Island lies only eight miles from the mainland. It two miles long, with sandy beaches full of penguins and seals. It would be pretty -- -- but for its MAXIMUM SECURITY PRISON. Concrete, barbed wire, guard towers. (In 1995, the political prisoner wing was shut, but the island still housed criminal prisoners, so the island sti had the feel of real incarceration. Today, it is a touris destination.)
As they approach the island, a sense of dark history sett over the Springboks and their partners. One of the Springboks turns to a DECKHAND, getting ready moor at the jetty.
How do they bring the prisoners here?
On this boat. Sobering.
The Springboks and their partners step onto dry land with some relief, look around at the prison, humbled. 103.
Imagine being able to see Cape Town so close by.

That would make it worse. They head towards the prison entrance, slowly becoming a tighter and tighter bunch. The ghosts of Mandela, and all the others who spent much of their lives here, are very strong.
VARIOUS SHOTS OF THE SPRINGBOK PARTY, in the EXERCISE YAR the LIME QUARRY, the MESS HALL. None of the usual horsing around. This place affects them, deeply.

Section B is the bleak political wing. Tiny cells line ea side of a damp concrete hallway. A PRISON GUARD shows the Springboks into the hallway, and they dwarf it, as they stand there, shocked. Shocked at w was done in their names. This group is as quiet as we hav ever seen them.
Can we see the President's cell?
Yes, of course. (leading them down past
We've done it up just the way it was. They reach a cell with a piece of white cardboard on the door, showing the number 466/64 -- MANDELA'S PRISON NUMBE
(pointing at the number) That means he was the 466th prisoner admitted in 1964. The Prison Guard unlocks the door, pulls it open, then unlocks the metal grill that is the inside door. 104.

Pienaar peers into the cell. It is tiny. There is no bed, just a sisal mat on the concrete floor, with a couple of blankets. A chamber pot, a short bench, a tin cup and pla are the only other objects in the room. A couple of small lockers are screwed high to the wall. T barred window is opaque. It lets in light but does not al the prisoner a view. When Pienaar enters, we see how small the cell really is. can reach out and touch the opposite walls at the same ti This is a bleak, horrible, dehumanizing place. Pienaar is stunned by it. He turns, slowly, looking at Mandela's wor for over twenty years.
The other Springboks and their partners wait to look into cell themselves, a little puzzled by how much time Pienaa taking.
Pienaar almost looks as if he is in a trance. He hears Mandela's voice in the cell with him.

Out of the night that covers me, Black as the pit from pole to pole, I thank whatever gods may be For my unconquerable soul. Now, Pienaar sees Mandela in prison clothes, in the cell. (The image is unclear, ghostly.)

In the fell clutch of circumstance I have not winced nor cried aloud. Under the bludgeonings of chance My head is bloody, but unbow'd. Pienaar sees Mandela sitting on the dirt in the prison ya breaking up rock with a hammer, along with rows of other political prisoners. 105.

Beyond this place of wrath and tears Looms but the Horror of the shade, And yet the menace of the years Finds and shall find me unafraid. Pienaar sees Mandela leading his fellow prisoners to the quarry, to mine lime under the eye of a guard who looks l Pienaar.
It matters not how strait the gate, How charged with punishment the scroll, I am the master of my fate: I am the captain of my soul.

The gates open. Linga gets out of one BMW, Hendrick out o the other. We know the routine. Only, Mandela doesn't appear for his walk. Linga and Hendrick wait for a moment, then head in through the gate
-- break into a sprint, when they see MANDELA'S FORM, CRUMPLED on the lawn.

Barbara, Mary, the house staff, plus Linga, Hendrick, Eti and Jason, all wait. All are scared. Nobody talks. The SOUND OF FOOTSTEPS from on the top floor brings them their feet. MANDELA'S DOCTOR descends the stairs.
What happened?
It's simple exhaustion, but it'll lead to worse if it's not treated. He needs complete rest. And I don't mean just shifting the affairs of state to his bedroom.
No phone calls, no visitors, no meetings. No politics.
You know him. He won't do that.
Then I'm going to put him into hospital. In isolation.
No. Not yet. I'll threaten him with hospital if he doesn't behave.
I'll cancel everything.
And I'll come back tonight to make sure he's not working. The doctor leaves. The rest of them look at each other, relieved ... and maybe a little guilty, for letting thing get this bad.
(to Mary, aside) Don't cancel the trip to Taiwan. Not yet.

Dark. Curtains drawn. The door opens quietly. A shaft of light from the door shows Mandela, on his back in bed, ey closed. Barbara enters. The sight of Mandela lying like this is chilling. It is too close to what he would look like lyin in a casket. Barbara makes sure he is breathing. He is. She unplugs hi phone, takes it. Unplugs his TV. Sweeps the room for papers, articles, legal briefs. For the first time, she takes an arm load of stuff away from him. She gives Mande one last, long look, closes the door behind her. We stay behind and look at Mandela, and ponder South Afri fate if this were worse than just deep, sedated sleep.
Chester Williams jogs under the tense eye of coach, train manager and Pienaar. He accelerates, running fast, but not sprinting.
That's not good enough. Chester opens it up. Full sprint, sustained. Pienaar grin Chester is back.
Let's hope the Samoans don't injure it again.
ONE, BRIEF SHOT of a typically brutal Samoan tackle, and ensuing foul play in the maul.
FOUR QUICK SHOTS of Chester williams scoring four tries.
ONE MORE SHOT of the Springboks trudging off the field. Every single player is bruised or bleeding, or both.

Looking frail, but better than before, Mandela pencils in score ON THE WORLD CUP BRACKET DIAGRAM: SOUTH AFRICA 42, WESTERN SAMOA 14. The diagram shows us that this was a quarter final match. We can see that he has entered all the South African scor (For the record: South Africa 27 - Australia 18; South Af 21 - Romania 3; South Africa 20 - Canada 0.) For the semi-finals, against South Africa, Mandela pencil France. 108. On the other side of the bracket, Mandela pencils in Engl vs. the All Blacks. With a satisfied grunt, Mandela steps back from the diagr Things are shaping up nicely. A knock at the door, and Barbara enters, ushering in a GR OF LABOR LEADERS.
Madiba, this is --
I know who this is. Beaming, exuding energy we know he doesn't have, Mandela rises to yet another occasion. He strides forward to shak hands.
Welcome, and thank you for coming such a long way to see me.
Monsoon rain batters the bus as it crawls towards KING'S STADIUM, in Durban.
Rain, rain, rain. The field is flooding.
Coach walks in on his team, who are dressed for the match ready to go.
Forty minute postponement. They're trying to clear the field.
A HUNDRED ZULU CLEANING LADIES with brooms and squeegees the water off the field. Capacity crowd cheers them on. (This happened. There will be stock footage.)
The boys stretch, jump, try to keep warmed-up.

Mandela and a negotiating team are meeting with their opposite numbers from Taiwan. A high-level affair that cannot be interrupted. Nonetheless, Mandela takes a discreet look at his watch, we realize that his mind is back home, with the Springbok
Pienaar leads his men out into the rain.

A quagmire, despite the efforts of the Zulu ladies. Muddy green and gold against the muddy blue, white and red of France. End of a close game. Both teams are tired, muddy and desperate. The French assault the Springbok try line, wave after wav The Springboks defend valiantly, but slowly go backwards. Finally, the French score a try -- or do they? CLOSE-UP ON THE RUGBY BALL, under a mountain of muddy men the ground three inches outside the try line. 110. The referee waves off the try.
Mandela flies home, still working intensely with a mixed South African/Taiwanese trade group. Mary slips a piece of paper in front of him, discreetly.

head_text.subj: ON THE PIECE OF PAPER IN EXCITED WRITING

text: Mandela's face betrays nothing. But, he gets up.
Please excuse me for a moment. With Mary leading the way, Mandela goes to the back of th plane, looking grave and leaderly -- -- but once he is through the galley curtain, he breaks i a huge smile.
This is very good ... very good! Who is our opponent?
The All Blacks play England tomorrow. Then, we'll know.
Please make sure that my schedule is clear for the entire match.
Yes, Madiba.

ON A BIG SCREEN TV in a private banquet room, the Springb team watches the England/All Black semi-final, which the Blacks dominate from beginning to end -- -- thanks to the exploits of JONAH LOMU, their unnaturall huge, fast left wing, of Tongan parentage (and unanimous choice for the best player in the entire World Cup). 111. Jonah Lomu scores in the first two minutes of the match, first of four tries. He runs through, over, and around hapless defenders. His speed and balance are almost unprecedented in a man his size. The Springboks go quiet as they watch this beating by the Blacks.
Mandela watches at home with Barbara and Mary.
Let's do some work while we watch. Barbara resists her natural impulse to work and says:
Just enjoy the rugby.
The sound of the match ON THE RADIO of one of the BMWs. Johan Lomu's name in every sentence. All the bodyguards are out of the cars, enjoying the wint sunshine as they listen to the match.
So, let me understand this. The All Blacks are killing a team that thrashed us last year?
Thanks for reminding me. Hendrick opens the trunk of their BMW, pulls out a RUGBY BALL, shows it to Linga. Linga nods. Okay. Throw it.
Another Lomu try, and a ripple goes through the Springbok 112.
We're going to have to tackle better than the English, that's for sure.
We do.
TV blares. Barbara does some work. Mandela comes and peek over her shoulder --
Are those the judicial appointments for the Free State? -- and Barbara shuts the file.
They'll keep until after the match.

A pile of guns in holsters, on the hood of a BMW. Suit jackets draped over the side mirrors. In the wide street, in their shirts and ties, the boys to the ball around. The white bodyguards handle the ball expertly, the black bodyguards for the first time in thei lives.
Give it a spin when you pass it.
Like this. Kwezi catches the ball, tries to throw it with spin, blow it. The ball bounces crazily all over the street, seems t have a mind of its own as it eludes Kwezi. They all laugh.
Lomu scores his third try.
How much does Lomu weigh?
About 120 kilos.
Shit, that's what I weigh.
Ja, but at least you're slow. As we will discover, the wing is going to have to defend against Lomu.
Mandela isn't watching TV. He's at the window, looking ou at a GAME OF TOUCH RUGBY, taking place on the street outs his house.
Come and look at this.
Two mixed teams. Hendrick passes to Linga, who passes bac to Hendrick, who scores.
You should've played rugby.
They wouldn't let me carry my gun. Laughter. This scene was unthinkable a year ago.

Barbara and Mary stand next to Mandela at the window. Mandela's eyes twinkle with pleasure as he hears the laughter. In a way, this small moment already justifies everything he has done. Almost. He gives Barbara a sly look.

Do you still think I'm wasting my time with the rugby? Before Barbara can reply, excitement on the TV makes Mand turn away. He looks at the TV just as Lomu scores his fou try, to make it 42 - 15. Mandela shakes his head, awed.
Barbara, can you please tell the Minister of Sport that I need a detailed briefing on the All Blacks. Barbara gives Mandela a long look.
This rugby, it's still strictly political?
Oh yes. Of course.
Pienaar hands an envelope to his father.
Don't lose them. I won't be able to get more. Mr. Pienaar opens the envelope, pulls out TICKETS TO THE WORLD CUP FINAL. Mr. Pienaar kisses the tickets.
Thanks, Francois. (fanning out tickets) Me, mom, Nerine -- wait, and the fourth? Who's it for? 115. Pienaar looks at his father, mischief in his eyes.
BMW, Mercedes, BMW, driving from Pretoria to Johannesburg the end of the day. Red winter sunset over the arid Highveld. GO `BOKS, GO AMABOKOBOKO signs, side by side. Chester and Pienaar billboards.
The All Blacks beat Ireland 43 to
The Minister of Sport gives Mandela his final briefing. A his side, Barbara thrusts papers in front of Mandela for signature. This continues throughout.
-- they beat Wales 34 to 9, they beat Japan 145 to 17.
145 points, in one match? Linga listens openly.
It's a new international record. (back to the briefing) They beat Scotland 48 to 30 in the quarter finals. You saw the match with England.
45 to 29. And it was not that close.
They seem unstoppable.
If opposing teams play them straight up, Jonah Lomu runs wild. If they focus on Lomu, that leaves others free.
And, also, there's the business of the haka. 116.
Their Maori war dance. Yes. It's very powerful.
My sources tell me that half of the All Black matches are won before the first whistle, because of it. Mandela peers out of the window at a Springbok billboard.
How are we going to beat them?
I have the coach's number. You could call him and ask.
No ... no. I don't want to break their focus for even a minute.
But, how do we win? ON LINGA: an idea occurs to him. A wild idea. He almost turns and blurts it out -- restrains himself.
Maybe we won't. They're favored two-to-one.
Madiba, we've already exceeded all expectations. On and off the field.
It's not enough. Not now. Not so close.
This country is hungry for greatness. Barbara pushes another paper in front of Mandela. He sign it.
The coach, the manager and Pienaar gather for a final briefing in the coach's spartan office. 117.
How's the feeling in the dressing room?
Calm.
And Lomu? Are they talking about him? Pienaar shrugs -- of course. Coach grins.
Nobody gives us a bloody chance. I like that. It plays into their one weakness. Both Pienaar and the manager look at the coach.
Their vanity.
They're already counting the win. But they want to win with style, the way they won all their other matches. They want to show the world how beautiful All Black rugby is.
I just want to show the bloody world how hard we tackle. Pienaar's up for that.
I wish tomorrow was already here.
Jason wishes tomorrow was already over. He goes through h plans, his check lists for the tenth time. He sighs, tries to roll the tension out of his shoulders, gives up. He leaves the office. 118.
Cops at their posts. Jason walks alone through the tunnel until he comes to a field entrance. He goes to the edge, looks out at the dimly lit field, trying to imagine tomor
(from behind him) Come on, man. There's nothing more you can do today. Jason turns to Etienne.
Have I ever mentioned to you that I hate rugby?
Once or twice, yes.
I just want to get him through tomorrow, safely. That's all.
We all do. A look between the two men: they are united. They have co a long way.
As in Cape Town, Pienaar stares out into the night, pensively. Preoccupied. So preoccupied, that when Nerine enters quietly, he hardl turns.
I brought one of your mom's protein shakes. Pienaar nods, thanks. Nerine puts the protein shake down. She tries to read Pienaar's mood, see what he needs from at this moment.
Thinking about tomorrow? 119.
No, tomorrow's taken care of, one way or another. Pienaar turns to her.
I'm thinking about how you spend 30 years in a tiny cell, but come out ready to forgive the people who put you there.

We have seen that solitary shape under the blankets befor We have seen the clock on the bedside table change from 4 to 5:00 before. We have seen Mandela's eyes open, immediately. But we have never seen Mandela roll over and go back to sleep. SUPER: JUNE 24, 1995 - RUGBY WORLD CUP FINAL.
The two BWMs wait faithfully.
Linga looks at his watch.
Hendrick does the same. Gets out.
Linga gets out, meets Hendrick at the gate.
Big day.
Be an even bigger day if we actually won. 120. Then, they both look at their watches again.
Where is he? They share a worried look. Linga reaches for his radio.

Mandela's bedroom door is opened from outside the room. Light from the hallway hits the bed. Mandela looks very still under the covers. Mary peers in, concern wiping away sleep. She sees Mandel lying there. Mary tiptoes in, concern growing, until she stands over Mandela -- -- who opens his eyes without moving otherwise.
Can a man not sleep in, when he has a big day ahead of him?
Mary's voice on Linga's radio.
Okay, thanks. Out. Linga lowers his radio, embarrassed.
He's sleeping in.
Or was. Linga and Hendrick stand at the gate for a moment, then t to head back to their respective cars. Linga pauses.
I had an idea. About today.
It's a crazy idea. 121.
Hey, don't worry, man. I already know you're crazy.

Mandela eats breakfast -- porridge and fresh fruit -- and looks over the newspaper headlines, all screaming about today's World Cup final. The doorbell rings, and he pauses, listens to the sound o voices at the door -- then the sound of heavy footsteps approaching through the house. Mandela wipes his mouth and waits. Linga and Hendrick app in the doorway. They look even bigger indoors.
Morning, boys.
Morning, Madiba.
What is it? Linga hesitates -- until Hendrick gives him a (for Hendri discreet nudge.
Linga had an idea, sir.
Mary walks briskly to her car, gets in and drives towards opening gate, fast.
Linga and Hendrick watch as Mary drives away. 122.
Now you've done it.

As in Cape Town, the Springboks jog through the streets. in Cape Town, cars toot their horns, people cheer. But the crowd running with them is twice as large as it w in Cape Town -- and twice as black. This crowd shows that the Springboks really do have the support of the whole country now. As the `boks rumble past, newspaper vendors, gardeners, pharmacy delivery men on small motorbikes abandon their t and run alongside the team. Pienaar turns to look at one of his teammates, grins, get grin in return.
Jason addresses his entire team (minus Linga), plus assor POLICE OFFICERS.
The tickets sold out long before the team became so popular. So it's not exactly going to be the rainbow nation out there. That's the reality.

The President will greet the players before the match, he'll present the trophy after the match. He'll be exposed to 62,000 people, twice. He'll be on TV, live, all over the world. (expressing his deepest
All it takes is one idiot trying to make a statement, or one crazy fool who thinks he hears god speaking to him over the radio. One of the cops smiles at that. 123.
It's happened before!
But not today. Not on our watch. Not today. The security boys are fired up.

It is hours before the match, but every entrance to Ellis Park stadium is chaotic with people, cars, face painters, flag sellers, fruit vendors. Cops everywhere, and everywh outnumbered. In the crowd outside, WE FIND SIPHO, collecting empty bot from trash cans, for recycling. Jason was right about the demographics of the crowd: whit khaki-clad, quite a few old South African flags among the of new flags. Springbok colors everywhere. We may even se the FOUR BOERE from the Lions debacle earlier.
Face flag?
Bugger off! Ellis Park isn't exactly the Rainbow Nation today.
We're at Ellis Park on this historic day, where, even this early, crowd excitement is at fever
Boland does another live remote. FANS CHEER AND WAVE behi
-- because their beloved green and gold have somehow managed to exceed all expectations.
A luxury bus pulls away from the hotel, with a FULL POLIC ESCORT, LIGHTS ON, SIRENS BLARING.
But now they come up against a team that is unlike any other they have played.
With that inward look of boxers before a big fight, the Springboks begin the journey to the stadium.
These All Blacks are possibly one of the greatest international sides ever, with a player in Jonah Lomu who is as dominant as any this correspondent has ever seen.
Mandela's Mercedes exits his gate, BMWs fore and aft.
To lose to them is no disgrace. To lose to them in the finals is, in fact, an honor.
Tight on Mandela's face, absolutely expressionless. His g face.
I say this with absolutely no negativity. I simply want to save people from the heartbreak of unrealistic expectations.
Back to Boland's live remote.

So, take a reality check, sit back and share an afternoon with one billion fellow fans around the world. And as you do, feel a special pride in having made it this far. This is Boland Botha, signing off and sitting back at Ellis Park. Huge crowd now, all around the TV truck, streaming in.
Driving down a secure access lane, the Springbok bus and police escort approach Ellis Park. And pass Sipho, who stares up at them from the sidewalk.
The boys are very quiet -- until the sheer spectacle gets them. Then, the first nerves hit. You can tell in the way they look at each other, the way they swallow.
Mandela's convoy pulls up at a secure entrance.

Stadium almost full. Crowd noise a dull roar. ABOVE THE SPRINGBOK BENCH, near the field, we find Nerine Mr. and Mrs. Pienaar ... and Eunice, as they take their seats. Pienaar got the fourth ticket for her. 126. Eunice turns to Mrs. Pienaar.
What's Mr. Francois doing now?

All dressed, all warmed up, the Springboks are quiet, introspective. Everything that should be said has been sa This is the calm before the storm. (NOTE that almost every player wears bandages, or braces, is injured in some way.) Pienaar is not in the room.
Dressed in his rugby togs, Pienaar sneaks up the ramp to edge of the field, takes a peek out of the tunnel -- -- and is blown away by the magnitude of it all.
Vast city seen from the air. Zero in on Ellis Park.
ANOTHER ANGLE of a SOUTH AFRICAN AIRWAYS 747 flying over city, in the direction of Ellis Park.
Final approach, Captain.
Let it be noted that I'm taking control of the aircraft. ANGLE BACK THROUGH THE COCKPIT -- NO PASSENGERS. 127.
I assume full responsibility for what happens from now on.
Duly noted. The captain drops the nose of the 747 towards Ellis Park.

Every seat full. Almost every seat filled by a big white man. Excitement unbearable. Jason stalks the runways between the seating sections, hi in the stadium. Binoculars around his neck, radio in hand Something catches his eye. Something in the air. Jason lifts his binoculars to his eyes. POV THROUGH BINOCULARS -- the 747 is heading right for th stadium. Jason lowers his binoculars. He frowns -- more puzzled th alarmed. (This is pre-9/11.) He lifts his radio to his mouth.
Do you see that jet, to the east?
Etienne, in another part of the stadium, looks eastwards sees it.
Did they get clearance for this?
Not from us. The 747 gets closer, fast. Jason is hit by a horrible thought. 128.
Where is he?
Jason finds the VIP box, looks out at the 747 -- -- and realizes that the jet is heading straight at that of the stadium.
Get him out of there. Now.
Mandela is not in his seat. Linga turns. Hendrick points the closed door of the VIP bathroom.
No time.
Nothing Jason can do about it but hold his breath as --
The captain drops the 747 even lower.
Jason has to fight down the impulse to flee.
Everyone in the VIP box sees the jet. They all stand.
The 747 nose appears over the rim of the stadium.
Full throttle. Captain and co-pilot go full throttle, yank the 747 strai upwards.
The ALMIGHTY ROAR OF FULL THROTTLES fills the stadium, as 747 passes less than 200 feet overhead -- -- so that everyone can read the huge letters painted on bottom of the wings:
(This really happened.) THE CROWD GOES WILD. JASON NEARLY FAINTS with relief.
Linga and Hendrick share a look. They have just had a bru with the unthinkable.
THE DRESSING ROOM VIBRATES with the roar ... 130.

What the hell was that? ... which slowly fades ... ... leaving only the background roar of the revved up cro The boys jog in place, dying for the release of rugby. Pienaar appears to be praying, silently.
The REFEREE walks off the field, into the tunnel, stands there for a moment, then raises his whistle to his mouth blows a LONG, ECHOING BLAST --
-- which is the signal to come to the field. The cop opens the door, throws down a full parade ground salute as Pienaar leads his men out of the dressing room.
Breathe, boys. Breathe.

WITH THE `BOKS, we head down the hallway, down some stair the tunnel onto the field -- -- where the referee holds his hand up like a traffic cop keeping the boys in a line in the tunnel. As they wait, they hear the CRUNCHING APPROACH OF BIG MEN CLEATS. Down the opposite stairway come THE ALL BLACKS. This is t first time we have seen them in the flesh. Huge men, black on black uniforms, arrogant. Been here before, done this before. The best in the world, expectin nothing but the best from the day. They ignore the Springboks, dismiss them, line up next to them in the tunnel. 131. The SOUND OF THIRTY MEN JOGGING IN PLACE in their cleats, the concrete, sounds like a drum roll before a medieval battle. The Springbok wing sneaks a peek at JONAH LOMU. The biggest, fastest wing ever. Even bigger looking in th confined space. Bigger than the Springbok wing, bigger th any of the Springbok backs, bigger than most of the Sprin forwards. The referee nods to both captains, turns, and leads them the field --

-- where the already-whipped up crowd goes crazy, as both teams sprint onto the field and go through their brief wa up ritual. WE FOCUS ON THE CROWD, focus on how white and old South Africa most of them are. The referee blows his whistle again, and both teams assem in a line, facing each other. Glaring like boxers across immaculate green grass.
Seen only in silhouette, Mandela walks down the tunnel. H is flanked by Jason, The Minister of Sport and the Presid of SA Rugby. Linga, as always, has Mandela's back. Plus Hendrick.

Mandela emerges into daylight, wearing not a suit, not a Madiba shirt -- -- he is wearing Francois Pienaar's green and gold number rugby jersey. On his head is THE SPRINGBOK CAP given to him by the team
The crowd catches its breath. This is unprecedented, shocking ... and brilliant. The Springboks digest this extraordinary display of suppo 132.

(murmuring to Pienaar) The All Blacks won't like that. Pienaar nods, eyes glinting. Mandela is giving them an ed As he walks towards the waiting teams, Mandela lifts the Springbok cap high, waves it, and fires his famous, beautiful, huge, African smile at the crowd -- -- who roar and stand, slowly, and start chanting, slowly
Nelson ... Nelson ... Nelson ... NELSON ... NELSON ... NELSON ... 63 000 South Africans, chanting as one.
ALL ACROSS SOUTH AFRICA, THE CHANT ECHOES through EMPTY STREETS. Not a soul, not a car to be seen. Everyone is inside, watching TV.
... etc. Mandela shakes hands with the Springboks, who are brimmin with pride. Mandela shakes Chester Williams' hand with special energy.
I'm so glad you're here. Chester beams.
IN THE STANDS, EUNICE ULULATES, loud African warrior woma call. Mr. Pienaar looks at her, shocked. Looks at her as person for the first time, maybe.
Eunice ululates again.
ON THE FIELD, Mandela shakes hands with the All Blacks, w as predicted, don't like his partisan clothing. Mandela looks up at Jonah Lomu.

Hello, Jonah. Lomu looks down at Mandela, eyes glowing with aggression -- and suddenly, he bares his tattooed Tongan tongue in a FIERCE WAR CRY. As do the rest of the All Blacks. WE HAVE SEGUED TO THE FAMOUS HAKA, a Maori war dance that tells an opponent they're going have their daughters stol their wives ravaged and their brains eaten right out of t skulls with a sharpened tea spoon. It is abundantly clear why, as the Minister of Sports tol Mandela, half of the All Blacks matches are won before th whistle blows. This is very intimidating. Especially because, this day, the All Blacks push the hak closer and closer to the Springboks -- -- who do not back down. In fact, they close ranks and advance. Major, major international smackdown. This is not fake. T emotions, the aggression are real. ON MANDELA, whose diplomatic mask slips a little showing warrior's glitter in his eyes. He wants to respond, primally. His fists clench at his side. The HAKA ENDS with a fearsome, guttural Maori yell. ON THE SPRINGBOKS, massed together, faces red with emotio pulses racing. Mandela takes a deep breath in. Then the boys answer. With, of course, a terrorist anthem of their own: NKOSI SIKELEL' IAFRIKA. 134. Pienaar starts it.

-- SIKELEL' IAFRIKA etc ... With decent pronunciation, with full fervor and heart, TH BOYS ROAR THE ANTHEM back at the All Blacks. The crowd joins them. "Nkosi" roars through the stadium, through the nation. ON MANDELA: his heart swells, as he sings with his people

ON JASON, who stands surrounded by his former enemies sin the song that kept him -- kept all of them -- going throu the apartheid years. In this stadium, at this moment, all hostility, all fear, a thing of the past. The tension finally goes out of Jason's shoulders. ON JASON'S FACE, close to tears, as NKOSI slowly fades. As Mandela said -- a very inspirational song. BEGIN HEARTBEAT OVER. Is that a heartbeat, or an African drum?
ON THE FIELD, the All Black fly half tees up the ball, fo kick off. As the fly half back-pedals slowly, and pauses in readine waiting for the whistle --
TO RAINBOW NATION FACES, poised all over South Africa, WATCHING ON TV and IN THE STANDS. Heart/drumbeat over. The last face is Sipho's.

The crowd noise spills out of the stadium behind Sipho. 135. A RADIO PLAYS NEARBY, tuned to the game. The radio is in cop car, manned by TWO BEEFY WHITE COPS. As the crowd noi rises, Sipho edges closer to the cops. They eye him out.
Mandela front and center. Minister of Sport to his right, Prime Minister of New Zealand to his left, President of S Rugby next to him. Both using all their diplomatic skills to stay cool.
(to NZ P.M.) Perhaps we should make a small wager? NEW ZEALAND P.M. All your gold, for all our sheep?
I was thinking more along the lines of a case of wine. Behind Mandela, Linga and Hendrick suppress grins. They a outwardly professional -- but bursting with excitement.

The referee blows his whistle. The All Black fly half boots the ball towards the Springb charges after it, along with the rest of the All Blacks. Game on. We have only seen snippets of rugby, so far. And mostly f a somewhat polite distance -- the usual distance of TV coverage. Say, at closest, the referee's point of view. Not now. Not for the climax. We experience this beautiful piece of mayhem up close and personal. We're inside the heaving scrums. We are the ball. We see the way cleats leave a pattern of round white dimples on abused skin, which quickly turn to purple as they fill wi subcutaneous blood. 136. We feel a tackle in our own spine; we see teeth sink into flesh in the intimacy of a loose scrum; we feel a hard fi smacking us again and again in the hot privacy of a rolli maul. For this is not a pretty match, not for one moment -- jus the Springbok coach wanted. This match is all about a less talented team stifling the best team in the world by sheer determination and fitness This is about the Springboks applying continuous, unrelen pressure, and forcing the vaunted All Black attack into making mistakes. Lots of them. Dropped balls, errant passes, knock-ons. No fluency of movement, no electric building of momentum. Because of one thing: tackling. Tackling and tackling and tackling again. The first time Lomu touches the ball, the stadium, the na holds its breath -- -- until the Springbok wing scythes into him at thigh hei wraps him up and brings him down. The second time Lomu gets the ball he is brought down fro behind by Pienaar, with a picture perfect tackle. We can cut away to the faces of the spectators when we wa from Mandela to Nerine to Sipho and on and on, all over t country. But, in truth, our attention belongs on the fiel ON PIENAAR, continually exhorting his men, leading by example, wreaking havoc in the All Black backfield. ON LOMU, who always seems just one broken tackle away fro running one in -- except that there are no broken tackles ON THIRTY BIG, STRONG, BATTLE-SCARRED MEN, who have devot their entire lives to this moment. They are not playing f money. They are playing for pride, for their countries. Outdated notions. We miss them. No tries are scored in the Final. The two fly halves matc each other, penalty goal for penalty goal. With each made kick, the goal posts shrink for the next. penalty goals are unchallenged. It is up to the kicker to make them or fail. That is pressure. 137. The score is 6 - 6 when, just before half time, the Sprin fly half takes a long, perfect pass from the scrum half, with the All Black defenders looming, kicks a drop goal through the uprights. The Springboks lead 9 - 6. A tight match. So tight, in fact, that there is only one score in the se half -- an All Black drop goal that levels the score at 9 9. Until right before the end of the match, when the All Bla camp in the Springbok half. The scrum half sends a long, spiralling pass to the fly h who is in perfect position to go for a drop goal. The kick soars into the air, high and straight. 43 million South Africans hold their breath. All around the world, fans lean forward on their chairs. This will be the decisive blow. But the kick just goes wide. Relief. The referee blows his whistle to signal the end of regulation. Both teams are spent.
What happens now?
Extra time. Twenty minutes.
I don't think I can take it. No one can. Mandela paces. Everyone is drained.
Sipho leans on the cop car, listening to the radio. He an the two cops suck nervously on sodas.
Two sets of bruised, bleeding, exhausted, cramping men fa each other for the extra time kick off. Pienaar turns to his men.

Who's the fittest team on this field? The answer lies in their eyes: they are. An All Black penalty goal makes it 12 - 9 almost immediat A Springbok penalty goal answers. 12 - 12. Seven minutes from the end of extra time, the Springboks a scrum deep in All Blacks territory.
Keep it here. Run it forward. The scrum goes down, wheels a little.

Francois! Pienaar turns his head. The fly half taps his own chest: give me the ball. Pienaar hesitates, then nods to the scrum half: give him ball. The ball goes into the scrum. The ball works its way back through the feet of the eight Springbok forwards. The scrum half gathers it, spins it out to the fly half - -- who takes one step to his left and KICKS A DROP GOAL h into the air. Ball soaring past a backdrop of open mouths. Higher than uprights ... ... but through them nonetheless. Springboks 15 - 12 All Blacks. An entire nation jumps to its feet. 139.
Everyone is on their feet in the press box.
How long before the end?
Seven minutes. They turn out to be the longest seven minutes in Mandela' life. In every South African's life.
This is where we fold the Rainbow Nation into the rugby match, fully.

head_text.subj: BETWEEN PEOPLE ALL OVER SOUTH AFRICA, AND THE RU

text: as we show the whole nation wanting exactly the same thin the same time. Faces, postures, eyes are identical, no matter where they are, who they are, what color they are. (It would be nice if we used all the faces we've already away to throughout this story.)

The All Blacks attack desperately. The Springboks tackle tackle and tackle. ON PIENAAR, totally spent but dragging himself to his fee for another tackle. He glances over at the referee, makes another tackle -- -- looks over at the referee -- -- the referee puts his hands on his whistle -- -- another tackle, another look -- -- the referee lifts the whistle to his lips -- -- another tackle, another look -- -- the REFEREE BLOWS THE FINAL WHISTLE. It's over. The Springboks have won. 140.
Pandemonium on the field, pandemonium in the stands. Jason is hugged by an ecstatic boer (Jason is not a hugge
Mrs. Pienaar and Nerine are in tears. Mr. Pienaar hugs a shocked Eunice.

Pandemonium in the VIP box. Mandela shakes hands with everyone he can find. It is way too loud to say anything. Hendrick and Linga almost hug. Almost. They shake hands with total joy and engagement, whack each other on the shoulder.
Sipho toi-tois next to the cop car (a township war dance, very political). The two cops toi-toi with him.
AROUND THE NATION, an EPIDEMIC OF HUGGING begins. This spills out onto the streets later, but for now, let's restrict this to the people who've been watching the matc together.

The Springboks say a prayer on the field. Pienaar kneels the middle, leading the prayer. Behind them, a WORK CREW ASSEMBLES A PORTABLE PODIUM. At "Amen", Pienaar's men lift him to his feet, then onto their shoulders. 141. The crowd roars again and again as PIENAAR TAKES A VICTOR LAP on the shoulders of the men he has led through thick thin. Tears stream down his face, through his unstoppable grin. As they near the podium, the team is intercepted by a new crew and -- -- none other then BOLAND BOTHA.
Francois ... a few words ... The interview booms through the PA system. Pienaar just n -- he isn't about to spoil the moment by reacting to this buffoon.
... great game, but I don't think you could've done it without the amazing support of these 63,000 South Africans -- Francois grabs the mike from Boland.

(into mike, words booming) We didn't have the support of 63,000 South Africans today. We had the support of 42 million South Africans. The crowd roars. The Springbok manager grabs Pienaar's shoulder, points.

They're waiting for you over there. Pienaar turns, looks. Mandela waits at the podium, eyes alight with joy. In front of him is the WILLIAM WEBB ELLIS TROPHY, a big g confection. Their eyes meet. Their eyes stay locked as Pienaar fights his way through press, the officials, his own team, to the podium. 142. Mandela holds out his hand. Pienaar takes it. Big hands, one black, one white, one with bruises visible, one with lifetime of bruises implied. Both wearing the NUMBER 6 SPRINGBOK JERSEY.
Francois, I want to thank you most sincerely for what you have done to our country. Pienaar shakes his head.

Mr. President, I want to thank you for what you have done. Eyes lock again, for just a moment, blue eyes, brown eyes African eyes, both. And then PIENAAR RAISES THE TROPHY HIGH. A very tradition sports hero's moment, richly deserved. Real gold, against the green of the battered field. But that is not the real prize. The prize is what happens next, all over the nation.

ALL OVER SOUTH AFRICA, people spill out into the streets, celebrate. Utter joy, everywhere, as black and white, servants and employers, strangers, enemies, foreigners are swept up in love and happiness. People who have been suspicious of each other, hated each other, feared each other all their lives ... they hug eac other on this day.

Housewives, gardeners, cops, kids dance in the middle of street. A car horn beeps politely. BMW, Mercedes, BMW come slowly down the street. 143. The crowd begins to dance and ululate as they part to let convoy through.
Linga in front. Mandela is alone in the back seat. He loo out at his people as they cheer him through. He also looks exhausted. Spent. None of that shining life force that makes him so big.
This route's too crowded. We're changing to route B.
The convoy switches to another street -- -- which is just as crowded as the first, with happy Sout Africans. It is as if every single person in the Rainbow Nation wan to celebrate together.
Change to route C.
The convoy switches to yet another street -- -- to no avail. South Africa is literally dancing in the streets.
Mandela leans forward, taps Linga on the shoulder. 144.
Tell Jason it's all right. There's no hurry.
Madiba says no need to hurry.
Jason nods, puts down his radio, settles back with a deep sigh. So do the rest of the boys in the car. This day is almost over.
Etienne, Hendrick loosen their ties, bask in the feeling. Hendrick looks out at the rolling street party -- and sha his head in amazement.

President Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela undoes the top button his rugby jersey, settles back with a deep sigh -- -- and drives home through a nation that has begun the process of forgiving itself. His nation. GO IN ON MANDELA'S FACE as it settles into the now-famili sphinx-like mask. Except for his eyes. Mandela's eyes glow with deep joy and satisfaction as he moves slowly through a moment in history that he has work for, all his life. ON MANDELA'S EYES ...
